dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home video footage of an African-American HAND holding up TUXEDO. We hear the elderly voice of its owner: CECIL V.O. This was the tux I wore on my first day workin’ at the White House on September 8, 1957. The video camera pans over to CECIL GAINS, 90, African- American. He is a kind, gentle soul wearing comfy sweatpa and a sweatshirt. We hear the male voice of the CAMERA MA

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: Who was your favorite president? Cecil smiles. He would never say who his favorite was.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I liked them all very much.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: Even Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I especially liked Mr. Nixon, and Mrs. Nixon was just lovely.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: What about LBJ? Cecil starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Well, he was...different, that’s fo’ sure, but a very special man.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: Did you ever meet a person you didn’t like? Cecil thinks about it, then his smile slowly drops.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: If the Devil wore a green bow in his hair, the good Lord woulda’ named him Annabeth Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNABETH LEWIS, 45, white, plump, wears a lacy dress and green bow in her hair. She screams at a young Cecil, 8.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: Every single field nigger on this farm wants to work inside the house! Why in the name of the lord and sweet baby Jesus should I take a puny little nigger like you?! Terrified, little Cecil stares out at thirty black FIELD WORKERS picking cotton in the hot sun.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: My ma just passed and my pa been gone a long tim--

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: Boo hoo! Little nigger don’t have no kin! Give me a real reason, boy! Little Cecil shivers, terrified:

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Cuz...cuz...I think yo’ green bow is awful nice, Mrs. Lewis. Her face turns bright red in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabeth is in the kitchen arranging chicken with lemon slices on an ornate gold tray. Cecil pays close attention

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: When you're servin’ you need to be as quiet as you can. I don’t even want to hear you breathe. A little scared, Cecil nods. ANNABETH WILLIAMS (CONT’D) The room should feel emptier when you're in it cuz no one likes a nigger. You understand me, boy? Cecil nods with simplicity, he understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil stands behind Annabeth holding a bowl of potatoes t she scoops on to her HUSBAND and three pre-teen SON’S pla Cecil holds his breathe, struggling to not make a peep. Annabeth serves with a distinct elegance, very delicate. Cecil closely eyes her every move as he quickly sips a ti breathe, then looks around to see if anyone noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Cecil lies awake in a tin shack filled with five o sleeping African-Americans of all ages. Everyone is cramm on the dirty floor, barely able to stretch their legs out Lying on his back, Cecil mimes pouring water. Practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil pours iced tea for Annabeth who reads Marie Curie’s autobiography. He puts in two spoon fulls of sugar and st

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: This is the one day I don’t want sugar. Make me another. Disappointed, Cecil takes the glass and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cecil walks back in with another iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: Is there honey in it? The look on his face clearly says no.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He walks back in and places another iced tea next to her. ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) I’ve decided I don’t want honey, I want sugar after all.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I brought it plain along with some options, Mrs. Lewis.  He gestures in Annabeth’s stylish manner toward the tray where there is a filled sugar bowl, a tiny jar of honey, lemon and lime slices, marble tea cakes and oatmeal cooki Annabeth forces herself not to smile as she gives Cecil a slight head bow. He is stunned at the first positive gest

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: There are no stirring spoo-- But Cecil is already stirring it with a silver stirring spoon. He sets it on a tray, then gives a slight head bow ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) Do you read, Cecil?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Lewis. She goes back to her book, flicks her hand at him to leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into the family library filled with leather b books. He opens a book and stares at the maze of words. W hear 90 year old Cecil in V.O.: CECIL V.O. I'd never seen anything so confusing in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil sits in the corner as everyone sleeps. Using a cand he places his finger under each word, silently mouthing i CECIL V.O. But after awhile I started to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is now 15 years old. He sits on the back porch eati grungy meat and potatoes next to the family dog, reading copy of ‘Huckleberry Finn’. He looks up from the book, sa CECIL V.O. Those books ended up being the worst thing to ever happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks around the cotton field, he looks deeply unha CECIL V.O. Until I started readin’, I always thought the world ended at the edge of the cotton farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabeth and Cecil serve the family. Annabeth sets fish o plate and Cecil debones it like a pro. A well oiled duo. CECIL V.O. I decided I wasn’t gone read no mo’ books. Annabeth has a huge fake smile, a servant in her own fami

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it was too late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at her chair, Annabeth stares up at Cecil, can’t believe what she’s just heard. She looks almost sad.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: But...why?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I wanna see some of the things I been readin’ about. I been savin’ up for almost three year now. Her face becomes very stoic. She goes back to her book.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH LEWIS
dialogues.text: That's fine. Leave when you like. She flicks him away. He stares at her, surprised and hurt that this is it after all these years. He walks to the do ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) Cecil. Cecil stops, looks back at her. There are tears in her ey ANNABETH LEWIS (CONT’D) I wanted to be a paleontologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil rides the rails in a freight train car with a knaps He stares at the barren landscape that flies by, enthrall Seated across from him are two grimy HOBOES, white. Excit by the ride, Cecil smiles at them...they don’t smile back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight beams in on a sleeping Cecil, blood CAKES his he He struggles to wake up as he feels the pain. He darts aw as he looks around - everything he has is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking down a dirt road with a blood soaked rag to his h he passes a charred abandoned factory with broken windows CECIL V.O. I started to understand why they were callin’ it a Depression. A PRISON TRUCK drives by full of BLACK PRISONERS, all cha together. Cecil stares at the truck, scared this will be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of ragged looking white men, women and kids, are l up in a grimy bread line. They SCREAM and hiss at Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE CROWD
dialogues.text: Go away!/Leave here!/Die, nigger! Little kids throw stones and rocks at him. Cecil runs awa INT. TIN SHACK — DAY A rainstorm hammers down upon Cecil who cradles himself i small tin shack. Water drips on his head. Drip Drip Drip. CECIL V.O. I would dream I was cleaning gold flatware... He looks like he’s slowly going mad. Drip Drip Drip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil stumbles in to a country town through pouring rain. peers in a window of a closed country store, sees groceri CECIL V.O. .+-and serving chicken au poivre from a silver tray. Transformed into a depraved soul, he finds a large rock, picks it up to throw it through the window... .--but he suddenly STOPS as he sees a glow in the distanc He slowly walks through the rain toward the glowing light The closer he gets, the more his eyes fill with fascinati He walks right up to an ornate glass window at a beautifu Southern HOTEL. Through the window he sees... Three BLACK MEN in elegant black tuxedos. They are placin gold forks next to china dishes in an opulent dining room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having cleaned up a touch, he is in the kitchen of the ho The HEAD BUTLER, black, 40's, glares at him with a meanne

dialogues.speaker: HEAD BUTLER
dialogues.text: So tell me, boy, why in the hell should I hire you!? Cecil turns to him with a warm smile, completely at ease.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I have found that it is better to serve, than be served. The Head Butler tries not to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is seated on a chair, still being filme

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: When did you end up in DC?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Ah, come on now. I got to start gettin’ ready for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: Just a few more questions.  Cecil sighs, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I got to Washington DC about ten years later. I went there to enlist so I could fight in the war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WEALTHY COUPLE walks in to the grand lobby of the Hotel Waiting for them with scotch on a silver tray is Cecil, n 25. He wears a black vest and tie, exudes class and grace CECIL V.O. ...but the army wasn’t so interested in takin’ negroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil delicately pours red wine into a glass decanter, a candle under it to see the sediments more clearly. CECIL V.O. And the negroes they did take, they only used for cleanin’ and servin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil shakes a martini shaker with grace and style. He tw off the top and effortlessly pours the martini into a gla CECIL V.O. But I wouldn’t have minded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil hangs a guest’s suit and shirt into the closet, the checks the buttons on the shirt, one at a time. CECIL V.O. I would've been happy servin’ a Colonel escargot in France... Discovering one of the buttons is loose, he pulls out a needle and thread from his pocket and begins to re-sew it

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...or pouring a General jasmine tea in Tokyo. Then, he hears CRYING in the next room. He peaks in and the shy maid, GLORIA, 22, black, crying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Gloria? She holds up a white dress shirt covered in a red wine st

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: The glass slipped. (Starts crying again) I can’t lose this job, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil holds the shirt under the sink as he vigorously rub bar of soap over the stain. She watches him, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: There's magic in a simple bar of soap, but it only works if the water is real hot. He holds it up, the stain is coming out. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Everyone say you real kind.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Ah, it ain’t nothin’. But she keeps smiling at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria stands in front of a PASTOR, wears a wedding dress

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I do. CUT TO - CECIL. He is next to her, looks slightly terrifi

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wedding reception is being held in the basement. A jazz band plays as dozens of people dance, drink and celebrate  10. CECIL V.O. I didn’t have no kin folk there, but Gloria sho’ made up for it. Cecil walks around serving cocktails. Gloria hurries over takes the tray. He shrugs, embarrassed, just can’t help i She escorts him to the dance floor as the band plays a sl tune. They slow dance, foreheads touching, madly in love.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Should I bring out hors devours? She shakes her head, no. Kisses him on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil carries Gloria into their honeymoon suite, a dank r with dirty carpets. They look like they are in Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie in bed next to each other, cuddling. Gloria look blissful, but Cecil seems pensive.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, baby doll?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I was just thinkin’ about Annabeth Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: That mean ole cracker woman?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I feel so sad for her. (Turns to Gloria) She neve’ had no one love her the way I’m gonna love you. Gloria starts to beam.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna give you a house and a family and I’m gonna take care of us for the rest of our lives. Nothin’ ever gonna tear my family apart. You hear me, honey bear?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I hear you, baby doll.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil changes his clothes in the run down locker room. Th HOTEL MANAGER, 50’s, white, walks in. He looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Cecil, there’s a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Gloria is in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil stands outside the hotel trying to hail a taxi, but none will stop. Panicked, he sees the Wealthy Couple gett into a Bentley. An awkward look as they know he needs a r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil runs down a street waving at cabs that won’t stop. sprints past a store with a ‘WHITES ONLY’ sign on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil runs past the US Capitol Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs past the Supreme Court of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries down the hallway of a dilapidated hospital, fi the door he’s looking for. A young NURSE, black, stops hi

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You can’t go in there. She needs rest.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Please, I need to see her--

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I said ya can’t go-- But he moves past her and hurries in to the room.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying on a hospital bed in a room with four other PATIENT Gloria, she looks terrible, exhausted. Cecil hurries to h

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You okay, honey bear?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Your son came early, baby doll. Tears fill his eyes at the news.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s a boy? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: And he don’t wait for no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in the hospital nursery holding his newborn baby who cries with all the other newborns. Cecil is in love.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I promise I’1l never leave you, Louis. His son continues to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothin’ ever gonna tear us apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gains house is packed with many NEIGHBORS, all Africa American, as Cecil walks around serving all of his friend fried chicken, biscuits and corn on the cob on a silver t CECIL V.O. Everything was real nice for a long time. Seated by himself in the corner is LOUIS, now 12 years ol little chubby, he reads a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You wanna join the group, Louis?  13. Cecil nods to the BOYS seated in the living room. Louis shrugs, ‘not really’. Cecil gives him an understanding wi A fun neighbor, HOWARD, 40’s, charismatic, grills the boy

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What do you want to be when you grow up, Elroy? A small boy in army fatigues, ELROY, 8, points at Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: I wanna work at a fancy hotel just like Mr. Gains. The room ‘ahhhs’ as Elroy’s mom, GINA, heavy, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: That’s my boy.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What about you, Louis? You want to work at a hotel like your dad? The room turns to Louis who looks unsure, a touch lost.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I...I don’t know. There is a moment of silence, Cecil looks almost embarras

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That's alright, Louis, you take your time. Cecil smiles at Louis, but it’s clear there’s the slighte ounce of concern for his son who’s a touch different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding a tray of martinis, Cecil approaches a table of WEALTHY MEN. A man with CREW CUT, 40’s, stern, searches h pocket for matches as he listens to a LOUD PATRON.

dialogues.speaker: LOUD PATRON
dialogues.text: The best decision that court ever made was to slow the whole mess down. Nigger boys in school with white girls?! Hell, we’d have another civil war! He sets his scotch down close to the table’s edge. Cecil glances at it, then notes how full the other glasses are.  14. LOUD PATRON (CONT’D) Cecil, what do you think of nigger kids in school with white folks? All eyes turn to Cecil, the Crew Cut Man paying particula attention as he keeps searching for matches.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (Refined voice) To be honest, Mr. Jenkins, I tend not to be too concerned with American or European politics. The Crew Cut Man smiles, liked the answer.

dialogues.speaker: LOUD PATRON
dialogues.text: Nor should you, Cecil, they’re all criminals. Earl Warren should be hanged. He’s the dumb son-of-a- bitch judge that said it was okay to integrate the schools.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I think Judge Warren is going to find that quite a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: LOUD PATRON
dialogues.text: Damn, straight, Cecil! He pats Cecil on the back, knocking the scotch off the ta In one motion, Cecil CATCHES it, places it in on the tabl and LIGHTS the Crew Cut Man’s cigar with his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: More spirits, gentleman? Puffing out smoke, the Crew Cut Man grins at Cecil. CECIL V.O. I didn’t know it then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil stares forward, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: ..-but things were about to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated by himself reading a comic book, Louis notices a g of kids huddled around something. He walks over to them.  15.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What are ya all lookin’ at? A TEEN holds up a copy of Jet Magazine opened to a grueso picture of a black teen boy’s CORPSE with a mutilated fac

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TEEN
dialogues.text: Emmet Till. Some crackers did this to ‘em in Mississippi for talkin’ to a white girl.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: How old was he?

dialogues.speaker: TEEN
dialogues.text: Fourteen. Louis can’t help it, he starts to cry. INT. CECIL’S CAR - DAY Cecil drives Louis home from school in his Ford 2 door. L stares in silence at his lower class neighborhood of smal but lively storefronts - grocers, liquor stores, restaura

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I got so upset at school.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: That magazine neve’ shoulda published that picture. They should be ashamed of themselves. Louis looks at his father.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Why did they kill him?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Emmet Till. He didn’t do nuthin’. Cecil doesn’t answer at first. Then -

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: The law is different fo’ colored folk than it is fo’ white folk. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's certain things that colored folk can’t do or say. (Then) Never get in trouble with the law, Louis, and you’ll be just fine. Louis stares at him, uneasy with what his dad just told h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is changing into his street clothes when the Hotel Manager sticks his head into the room, he looks concerned

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Are you in trouble with the law?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: The Secret Service just called me asking about you. Cecil stares at him, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks up to the Blair House, a federal-style townho that faces the WHITE HOUSE. He glances at the White House takes a breath, then walks into the Blair House. INT. FREDDIE FALLOW’S OFFICE - BLAIR HOUSE - DAY Cecil sits in a small office, finely furnished with turn the century antiques. He sits across from FREDDIE FALLOWS black, mid-50’s, has the formality of English royalty.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Are you political, Mr. Gains?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Good, we have no tolerance for politics at the White House. Slight beat.  17.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Forgive me for asking, but how did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: (Icy) I didn’t. You served RD Warner at the Excelsior Hotel a few years ago. He is the Chief Usher here which means he oversees operations for the entire House. Needless to say, you made quite an impression.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A few years ago?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Warner and myself make note of potential staff around town, but butler positions rarely open as most stay on for 30 years or more.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I see. It was quite a surprise getting the call.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: It was a surprise for me as well. As the White House Maitre D’, I normally hire the butlers. Cecil immediately knows that Freddie doesn’t want him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Forgive me for saying this, Mr. Fallows, but I certainly wouldn't want to be hired under circumstances that would make you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. Your job must be immensely challenging, serving the President of the United States. You need butlers that you’ve hand picked, men to your liking that will fulfill your vision of a proper White House staff. Cecil glances at a collection of crystal doves on his des  18.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are these baccarat? Freddie looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Waterford is pleasant, and the Irish certainly make a great whiskey, but I think the French have a distinct advantage when it comes to crystal. Freddie stares at Cecil for a beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Would you care for a demitasse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria, Louis, Gina and Elroy and several neighbors are a in the living room, waiting. Elroy is very excited, but L looks indifferent, reading a book. From upstairs they hea

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Y'all ready? They all shout ‘yes’ in unison. Cecil slowly walks down t stairs. They first see his shiny shoes, then his sleek pa and finally the full view - a perfectly tailored tuxedo. The entire room applauds as Gloria tears up, so proud.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: My baby is the President’s butler. Elroy is in total awe, but Louis looks a little uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in his car in the employees parking lot that overlooks the South Lawn, directly behind the White House gets out and looks around, eyes peeled open in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks down a treeline pathway toward the side entra where flags stick out of lamp posts. He stops at the Secu Gate, a shed with a glass window.  19.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: My name is Cecil Gains. I’m the new butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Freddie walk through the elegant first floor of entrance hall. Marble walls with red carpet and pink tile floors, a French palace and a museum rolled into one. Four HOUSEMEN, all black, late 20's, are setting up ropes barriers and tables for the White House tour.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: We have six houseman who are primarily responsible for furniture and chair arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Six men just to move the tables? Freddie gives him a ‘you have no idea’ look.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: There are over 70 full time employees at the House. They walk the Cross Hall passing the Presidential portrai

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 16 maids, 6 butlers, 4 carpenters, 2 painters, 7 electricians, 9 engineers, 2 plumbers, 2 grounds keepers, 3 florists, 2 pantry men, 3 dishwashers, 3 doorman, 4 florists, a full kitchen staff including pastry chef and 3 full time calligraphers. Freddie nods at a small MAN who sets a clock in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Joe sets all the clocks.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: That’s his only job?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Every hour of every day, he makes sure that every clock is set to the exact time.  20. The Crew Cut Man from the hotel, RD WARNER, walks by. Cec eyes light up, he steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Mr. Warner, I just want to thank you for this opportuni-- But RD Warner keeps walking, doesn’t even acknowledge him Cecil is surprised by the snub. Freddie whispers in his e

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: The Chief Usher is not overly friendly with the colored help. Cecil nods, he gets it. INT. WHITE HOUSE - BUTLER’S LOCKER ROOM - MORNING Cecil enters the plain locker room with chipped benches. butlers are changing into tuxes, BOOKER PARKER, 32, short fiery, and CARTER WILSON, 40, stocky with a solemn demean

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Ten to one those kids never see the inside of that classroo--. They immediately clam up as they see Cecil. Eyeing the ne guy. Cecil holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I’m Cecil Gains, the new butler. Carter shakes his hand first.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Carter Wilson, head butler and this is Booker Parker, second butler.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Where ya stand on civil rights, blood? Cecil is taken back. Carter shoots Booker a frustrated lo

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Why don’t you shake the man’s hand first? Booker holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.  21. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So where do you stand on civil rights, blood?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Don’t mind Booker, he’s just angry his name is Booker.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Of all the goddamn names!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I thought we weren’t supposed to discuss politics.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Out there in the White House, but you in the black house now, boy, and I’m just a blood that’s curious where the other blood stand.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: You don’t have to answer, Cecil, no one else does. Cecil turns to Booker, smiles with warmth.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I don’t think those negroes down South want any more trouble than they've already got.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Amen to that! Carter high fives Cecil. Fast friends. Booker smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: That's alright, that’s alright. (Upper crust voice) Now if you gentleman will excuse me, the First Family needs their filet mignon and Grand Mariner. A pleasure meeting you, Mr. Gains. He bows his head, then walks out. Carter smiles at Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Welcome to the House.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Fallows stand in the State Dining Room, an eleg room with ornate gold curtains, gold chandelier and a mas portrait of Abraham Lincoln over the marble fire place. They hover over a dinning table covered in the finest chi crystal and flatware. Freddie points to the crystal glass

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: The glasses are always placed in the following order: Water, white, red and flute. Always serve from the left and when lifting a plate-- He leans in from the left and effortlessly lifts the plat

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --you must never scrape the bottom. The tinkle of silverware will get an immediate report to me which I report to the Chief Usher. Cecil nods, but it’s clear that this is serious business.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must never listen or react to a conversation. The room should feel--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: --emptier when I’m in it. Freddie nods.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: And never ever rush service, because Mrs. Eisenhower is watching you like a hawk. As if on cue, the door opens and in walks MAMIE EISENHOWE 59, with her SOCIAL SECRETARY. In a sundress, Mamie dress youthful with curly bangs, but she acts like a general.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE
dialogues.text: Freddie, I just finished tonight's menus. I’ve decided to change asparagus to green beans. The Social Secretary hands Freddie the menus.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Very good, Mrs. Eisenhower. Allow me to introduce our new butler, Cecil Gains.  23. Cecil gives a slight head bow.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A true honor, Mrs. Eisenhower.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE
dialogues.text: Never rush service, Cecil, and you'll be alright with me. (Turns to Freddie) Speaking of which, at the Navy dinner, I noticed that on three separate occasions, Roger picked up courses too soon. This is the third time I’ve mentioned his service.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: It is unacceptable, Mrs. Eisenhower and I assure you that his presence will no longer be required. Cecil looks surprised, it’s cutthroat here. Mamie feels b

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, now, that’s not necessary, Freddie, give him one more shot.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: I prefer not, Mrs. Eisenhower, he has tried both our patience.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE
dialogues.text: Well...if you insist. Mamie smiles at Cecil, flipping from General to hostess.

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome to the House, Cecil, I hope your time here is pleasurable. And with that, she moves on as quickly as she came.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Let's begin, shall we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in the small kitchen with steel appliances and cabinets. He places a teapot on a silver tray as the STAF black, shoot him glances, they know it’s his first servin As he lifts the tray, a photographer takes a picture of h to record the moment. He looks fantastic in his fitted tu holding a beautiful tea set. Freddie whispers in his ear:  24.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: You hear nothing, you see nothing, you only serve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks down the hall to the corridor entrance of the Oval Office. A tiny bead of sweat forms on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into the corridor, a SECRET SERVICE AGENT stops

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Tea for the president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks in to the Oval Office and sees DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER standing upright at attention by his desk. His presence is enormous, but he exudes a grandfatherly warmt Cecil tries not to stare at him, but it’s hard not to. He sets the tray down and begins to pour a cup of tea. Two other men are seated on the sofas - the Chief of Staf SHERMAN ADAMS, 56, tough and harsh, is in an argument wit Attorney General, HERBERT BROWNELL, 51, calm and low keye

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN ADAMS
dialogues.text: So what are you suggesting? Sending federal troops to Little Rock?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT BROWNELL
dialogues.text: If it comes to that, then yes. Cecil picks up the cup and saucer, but it rattles as his SHAKES from nerves. He grips the cup with the other hand stop the rattling and carefully sets it down on Ike’s des Ike steps forward, his presence overtakes the room.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I can’t see any situation where I’d send troops to the South. Ever. It would cause another Civil War. Cecil begins to pour another cup, his hand shakes even mo He’s not listening, totally focused on not spilling.  25.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT BROWNELL
dialogues.text: If the Federal government doesn’t enforce Brown, then who will? The South must comply with the law.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: The South has been in compliance with the law for the last 60 years. They've built their entire society around the law. Then, in one day, that damn fool Earl Warren tells them their entire way of life is now illegal. It’s going to take some time for them to adjust. Cecil pours another cup, but a tiny bit of tea pours over edge. He quickly takes out a napkin and drys the saucer.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT BROWNELL
dialogues.text: I understand, Mr. President, but if Faubus continues to block the negro children, then we must enforce the Constitution. Cecil places a cup of tea in front of Sherman Adams, tryi to be as obsequious as possible.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN ADAMS
dialogues.text: Let’s give Faubus more time. With a little persuading, he’1ll back down. We just want to move slowly. Ike sips his tea as he struggles through his feelings.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I am for moderation...but I am also for progress. (Then) That is exactly what I am for. Cecil grabs his tray and hurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking out of the Oval Office, sweat freely pours down Cecil’s face. He dabbles a handkerchief on his forehead. CECIL V.O. I was so scared I didn’t hear one word those men said.  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil serves Gloria, Louis and Elroy dinner as everyone listens with rapture.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Then my hands started shakin’.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Did you spill, Mr. Gains?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A little, but I cleaned it before anyone saw.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What did the President talk about?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You know I can’t tell anyone that. Gloria nods, a little disappointed, but understands.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Butlers know secrets?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: They know everything, but they tell nothing. That’s the butler’s code. Elroy grins, very exciting. Louis clears his throat, loud

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got a bone in your throat or you got something to say? Louis takes out a flyer and hands it to his dad, it reads ‘MAMIE TILL, MOTHER OF EMMET TILL, SPEAKS OUT!’

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I really want to go to this.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. No way.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Nuthin’ good can come goin’ to this sort of thing. Nuthin’. I’m sorry, Louis, the answer is no. Gloria glances at Louis who can’t hide his disappointment  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria and Louis are in a packed African-American church.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You promise you won’t tell your father I brought you here? Louis nods, so thrilled to be there. Up on the stage walk MAMIE TILL, 34, black, pretty. The audience gives her a w round of applause. She walks to a podium next to a large black & white pictu on a pedestal of the smiling Emmet Till. On another pedes is the photo of his mutilated corpse. She speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE TILL
dialogues.text: If I should cry for the rest of my life there wouldn’t be enough tears for my son Emmett Till. The audience yells ‘That’s right!’ and ‘Tell it like it i

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE TILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just a quiet house wife from Chicago, I never once saw myself as having the courage to stand up in front of people and speak my mind, but we can’t allow what happened to my boy to ever happen again! The audience jumps to its feet, screaming with fire. Loui yells, transformed by Mamie Till who looks right at him:

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE TILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all gonna be tested... Louis is taken aback, he never thought he would be tested INT. WHITE HOUSE - IKE’S BEDROOM —- MORNING Ike stands in front of his VALET, a Filipino man in a Nav uniform. The Valet buttons Ike’s shirt up for him. MAMIE TILL V.O. .--and only then will we see who is truly on the side of the righteous. Ike stares forward in deep thought, very conflicted. Cecil walks into the room with a coffee as the Valet take the President’s dirty pajamas and exits. Ike sips the cof  28.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Cecil, did you mind going to an all colored school?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I didn’t go to school, Mr. President, I grew up on a cotton farm. Ike stares at him for a beat, then nods. As Cecil turns t leave, he sees a furious Sherman Adams in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN ADAMS
dialogues.text: The State Guard just blocked all the colored kids from entering the school again.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Faubus promised me he’d let them in.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN ADAMS
dialogues.text: The Governor lied, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike sits behind his desk as he speaks directly into a TV camera. Sherman Adams and Herbert Brownell are in the roo

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I have today issued an Executive Order directing the use of troops under Federal authority to aid in the execution of Federal law at Little Rock, Arkansas. Brownell shoots Sherman Adams a subtle look, Adams shrugs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil, Booker and Carter watch the announcement with the dishwashers in the kitchen. Everyone has a look of pride.

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: ‘Thus will restore the image of America and of all its parts as one nation...’  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Elroy walk to school as we hear Ike finish up: IKE V.O. “,..indivisible with liberty and justice for all.”

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Does this mean we're all gonna go to white schools now?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Probably not right away, but I bet by the time I graduate high school, every school will be integrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge auditorium is packed with friends and family for a high school graduation ceremony. The PRINCIPAL, black, announces the names of the graduates.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Sarah Feener. In cap & gown, she walks across the stage to get her dipl PRINCIPAL (CONT’D) Louis Gains. Cecil, Gloria, Elroy, Gina and all the neighbors cheer li crazy as Louis walks across the stage. Three years older, Louis is a fit, handsome, but still shy young man. We PAN ACROSS the rows of the GRADUATES in cap and gowns every single one is black. There has been no integration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Louis drag a trunk full of clothes to the cargo load of a Greyhound bus as Gloria waits by the door.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna go all the way down to Tennessee?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Fisk is a really good school, dad. Cecil tries to smile through the pain of losing his son.  30.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I know, I know, it’s just so far away. That’s all. Louis looks right at his dad.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: That’s the point. He walks back to his mom. Cecil is taken aback, confused. Gloria awaits by the bus door in tears, she hugs Louis.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe my boy is going off to college. Then Cecil hugs Louis, holds on to him a little bit longe than he should, just doesn’t want to let go.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You're the first person in this family to ever go to college.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I know, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You make me proud, Louis, you make the whole neighborhood proud. I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I love you too, Dad. Cecil finally lets go. Louis takes a deep breathe, then g on the bus. The white BUS DRIVER nods to him to go to the back, Louis nods back, no problem, sits at the back. As the bus pulls away from the station, Louis waves to hi parents who wave back. They hold each other as they watch their son go off to college, a sadness filling their soul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil stares forward with the same look from bus station, sadness. The Camera Man changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: So what was a typical day like?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What?  31.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: At the White House. What was a typical day like? Cecil smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: There was no typical day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP - an escargot dish filled with delicious snails. Cecil sets the tray down in front of the President of Fra CECIL V.O. One day I'd be servin’ escargot to President Charles De Gaulle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil hands Ike a putter on the South Lawn putting hole. CECIL V.O. ...the next day I’d be a caddy. Ike misses the shot, slams the putter on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil smiles into the camera with pride.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I never did make it to Japan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil pours tea for Japanese EMPEROR HIROHITO. CECIL V.O. .--but I did get to pour tea for Emperor Hirohito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weary Cecil and Booker place the Truman China back into boxes. The room is filled with all of the White House Chi CECIL V.O. We always worked long hours...  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil, Booker and Carter help the pastry chef, LUKE JA’DE 50's, passionate, make an elaborate french dessert. CECIL V.O. .--but I loved every minute of it. The Vice-President, RICHARD NIXON, 47, walks in. He feels like the kid in school that desperately wanted to be like

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I brought you gentleman something very special. Nixon pulls out four buttons that say ‘NIXON FOR PRESIDEN 1960’. The butlers all ‘coo’, immediately put them on.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: We’re all cheering for you, Mr. Vice-President. Carter nods but Booker smiles a little too wide.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Now I don’t want to say anything negative about that Kennedy boy, I’m sure he’s a fine fellow, but do you really want a spoiled rich brat who never lifted a finger in his spoiled rich brat life to be your next president!? Everyone shakes their heads as Nixon dabs a handkerchief his forehead. Nothing gets him angrier than Kennedy’s wea

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now let me ask all of you, as members of the negro community, what are your biggest concerns? The Butlers all stare back at him, no one wants to answer

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, don’t be shy. I want to have a focus group here.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Vice President, the colored help gets paid almost 40% less than the white help.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: You don’t say?  33.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, and it’s very difficult for us to be promoted. There isn’t a single colored houseman that’s been made an engineer and many of them have been here for years.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I tell ya what, Booker, when I’m President, the first thing I’m going to do is look into getting you gentleman the raises and promotions you deserve. Of course I’1ll have to check with certain oversight committees and the National Trust foundation, if we have one, but I’1l definitely look into it. Booker grins, doesn’t buy it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: That would be swell, Mr. Vice President.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: What about you, Cecil? What are your concerns? Civil Rights?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Oh, no, sir, that’s none of my business. I just want my boy to have a good education.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Damn straight. LUKE JA’DEAN Zezil’s zun just went off to college.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: What? LUKE JA’DEAN His zun just went off to college?

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER AND CARTER
dialogues.text: His son just went off to college.  34.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Ohhhhh. ‘Son’. Got it. The accent. Well congratulations, Cecil, what a fine accomplishment, just fine. Where’s he going?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Fisk University. Richard Nixon’s face drops. All of his ‘campaign’ enthusi vanishes as the shrewd Tricky Dick pops out.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: In Nashville? Cecil nods. Nixon leans into him.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell does he want to go to the deep South for? All eyes on Cecil who shrugs, he doesn’t really know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis is in a rundown area, wooden shacks with dirt lawns holds a flyer with a picture of a Hindu Goddess on it, written across the top is ‘FELLOWSHIP OF RECONCILIATION’.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You lookin’ for love? From out of the shadows steps CAROL BLUE, 19, black, wear school girl skirt and has her hair in a modern coiled fla Carol exudes a natural charisma, outgoing and brash.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what some of us are calling the Lawson workshop, the love school. Is that what you’re lookin’ for?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s why I came to Fisk.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Me too! (Holds out her hand) I’m Carol Blue.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Louis Gains.  35. They shake hands, but she doesn’t let go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well come on then, Mr. Gains, Mr. Lawson is awaitin’ us! She drags him toward a small red brick chapel on the corn

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn, boy, I’m amazed I saw you, you the darkest nigger I eve’ seen. Louis blushes, he’s in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is full of COLLEGE STUDENTS, all black, they lis to JAMES LAWSON, 29, black, bespectacled. Very zen, mysti

dialogues.speaker: JAMES LAWSON
dialogues.text: Satya is truth which equals love. Agraha means force. He points to a picture on the wall of MAHATMA GHANDI. JAMES LAWSON (CONT’D) Mahatma Ghandi combined them into one word, Satyagraha, to mean love force. This is the foundation of his philosophy of non-violent resistance and it’s what Martin King used in his bus boycott a few years back. We will study Ghandi’s techniques to train you to become an army, but in this army, your only weapon will be love.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: James Lawson has his jacket off, sleeves rolled up. Every is paired up into teams of two seated across from each ot JAMES LAWSON (CONT’D) When they scream at you, visualize them as a baby...a time before they were taught to hate.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Carol curls into a fetal position as a student ‘kicks’ he JAMES LAWSON (CONT’D) Always protect your vital organs.  36.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Louis is surrounded by students yelling and spitting on h JAMES LAWSON (CONT’D) It’s not enough to resist the urge to strike back. You must have no desire to strike back. You must love the person that’s hitting you, you must love the hell out of them, because that is the only way you can change their heart. James Lawson steps forward to make the most important poi JAMES LAWSON (CONT’D) For it is only when they learn to love you back that we will truly become a Beloved Community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Carol walk down the street with three students. men in suits, women in blouses, all nervous, but determin Carol grabs Louis’ hand as they walk hand in hand toward WOOLWORTHS DEPARTMENT STORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty butlers and housemen are setting up for a State Dinner. Cecil sets down a plate followed by Carter with t gold flatware, followed by Booker with the wine glasses. RD Warner stands under the painting of Abraham Lincoln as black staff scrambles to set up the ornate room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five students get off the escalator and walk right up the LUNCH COUNTER. It is half filled with WHITE PATRONS. The black students sit down at the counter. The white pat immediately look at them. A WAITRESS drops her tray.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Y'all can’t sit here. But the students stare forward, they aren’t going to move  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILITARY AIDES escort LADIES in dresses into the East Roo their MALE dates tag along. As they all line up on the re carpet, the doors to the State Dining Room open revealing The BUTLERS upright at their stations dressed in tailed tuxedos. The candle lit tables are covered in the finest china, flatware and crystal. A vision of pure opulence.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY AIDE
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, the President and First Lady of the United States. The Military Band strikes up ‘Hail to the Chief’ as Ike a Mamie walks down the corridor lined with Military Aides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having sat for hours, the students still sit at the count reading books as many white ONLOOKERS stare from a distan Concern fills Carol as she points toward the escalator - A group of angry white TEENAGERS are walking toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the guests are seated at their tables as Cecil and butlers stand at attention. Freddie nods at the butlers w start serving filet of sole. Cecil elegantly sets one dow

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: Do you think I could have some ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A White Student DUMPS ketchup on Carol’s head. Others lau as they squirt mustard on them. The black students stare forward in zen calm as Louis looks at the counter Manager

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We would like to be served, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil sets down the next course of French lamb chops with minted pears in front of a FEMALE GUEST who is so delight she kisses her HUSBAND on the cheek.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aggressive student with a CREW CUT punches Louis in th face. Louis FLIES off his stool onto the ground. Carol jumps on Louis followed by the black students to fo coordinated protective ball. The Crew Cut student pulls L out and punches him. Louis looks him in the eye as he hea JAMES LAWSON V.O. You must love your attacker. He punches Louis again. JAMES LAWSON V.O. (CONT’D) Love him with all your heart. As Louis looks up, a massive GLOW OF LIGHT shines behind attacker, a light that is pure and bright and beautiful. JAMES LAWSON V.O. (CONT’D) For it is only when they learn to love you back that we will truly become a Beloved Community. Louis's eyes light up into a trance-like state, he’s havi mystical experience. A smile forms on his bloodied face because Louis now loves this man. Five POLICE OFFICERS hurry into the lounch counter area a immediately handcuff Louis and the other black students.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: You are all under arrest for disorderly conduct. The White Students CHEER as the bleeding black students a lead away. The Crew Cut student grins, until he sees - Four new BLACK STUDENTS are now SEATED at the lunch count

dialogues.speaker: NEW LEAD STUDENT
dialogues.text: We would like to be served, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the butlers are lounging in the kitchen. They are exhausted as they hold up wine glasses for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: To serving our country. Cecil beams, proud of his work as he clinks his glass.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five students are escorted to a police paddy wagon as they peacefully sing their anthem, ‘We Shall Overcome’:

dialogues.speaker: BLACK STUDENTS
dialogues.text: ‘We shall overcome. We shall overcome. We shall overcome some day.’ Up and down the street, 100 black STUDENTS are being haul into police paddy wagons as mobs of whites scream at them This was a coordinated sit-in all over downtown Nashville

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty-two proud students, mostly black but a couple whit are seated in a packed courtroom. Louis and Carol sit nex each other, smiling, proud. Then - Louis’s smile drops. He sees Cecil standing in the back of the courtroom, his father looks horrified. Louis walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A furious Cecil scolds Louis in a corner of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I worked every day of my life, every single day, to give you the opportunities I never had. And this is what you do with it?!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. Something is happening here, something special.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Ain’t nuthin’ special about a nigger in jail!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We're standing up for our rights. We’re going to change the nation’s consciousness toward the American negro.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You're what?!  40.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We're changing the national consci--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: All ya’ doing is breakin’ the law! And it’s gonna get you and a lot of other folks killed. I didn’t send my boy off to college to go to his funeral!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: If I can’t sit at any lunch counter I want, then I’m not really alive.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Nuthin’ good can come of this. All you’re gonna do is make white folks angrier and get a lot of negroes hurt. That’s what always happens.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: That's what we’re going to change. Cecil stares at him, angry and scared.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You don’t understand, Louis, the law doesn’t work for us, it’s always against us. Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE JACK HARRIS, balding and heavy, sits up on the benc staring out at the courtroom. The attorney Z. ALEXANDER LOOBY, 61, black, sharp, stands up in front of the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Z. ALEXANDER LOOBY
dialogues.text: Your honor, the charges of disorderly conduct have absolu-- Judge Harris turns his chair AROUND so his back faces the court, he’s not going to listen. The students gasp in sho Z. ALEXANDER LOOBY (CONT’D) --absolutely no merit. These students were calm, quiet and in compliance with all conduct laws. The Judge's back is still to the court. Looby speaks loud Z. ALEXANDER LOOBY (CONT’D) The mob that beat them are the ones that should be tried for disorder--  41. He throws up his arms and yells at the Judge. Z. ALEXANDER LOOBY (CONT’D) What’s the use! Judge Harris turns back around and faces the students.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HARRIS
dialogues.text: I find the defendants guilty of disorderly conduct and sentence them to thirty days in the county workhouse or a fine of $50 each. Carol leaps to her feet. She calmly announces to the Judg

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We feel if we pay these fines we would be supporting the injustice and immoral practice that have been performed in our arrest and conviction.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HARRIS
dialogues.text: Ya’all feel that way? All of the students rise to their feet in solidarity. JUDGE HARRIS (CONT’D) Enjoy the big house, kids. He SLAMS his gavel as we CUT TO -

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of news clips of sit-in’s all over the country. NEWSCAST V.O. “Sparked by the Greensboro and Nashville sit-in’s a phenomenon has erupted across America.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the neighbors are outside the Gain’s house, everyo is talking, gossiping, concerned looks are shared.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That boy is gonna get us all killed. Several people nod in agreement.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scared Gloria watches the news coverage of the sit-in movement with more neighbors. Gina has her arm around her

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCAST, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: “Thousands of negro students joined by some white students have been ‘sitting-in’ at department store lunch counters...” Cecil is in the staircase staring at an old family photo during happy times, he is filled with a deep concern. NEWSCAST V.O. “,..in protest of their policies of only serving white patrons.” Elroy tugs on his leg, he’s scared.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Can the President help Louis? Cecil stares back at him, not sure of the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Mamie stand in front of the entire staff.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: From the bottom of my heart, I want to thank you for everything you did for us. These last eight years... Ike tears up, Mamie finishes for her husband who can’t sp

dialogues.speaker: MAMIE
dialogues.text: ...they’ve been the most special years of our lives, and much of that we owe to all of you. The staff is in tears too as they applaud. Even Booker cr CECIL V.O. There’s nothin’ sadder than sayin’ goodbye to the First Family. Ike and Mamie say tearful good-byes to each one individua

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've spent every day with them for the past eight years, and in less than an hour, they gonna be gone.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil shines a pair of black dress shoes, he looks up into the video camera.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Transition is hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every member of the White House staff carry moving boxes haul furniture down the Center Hall. CECIL V.O. The rule is that the President lives at the White House until the moment the next one is sworn in. The Chief Usher, RD Warner, keeps glancing at his watch a the staff carries out the Eisenhower’s personal belonging INT. WHITE HOUSE - IKE’S BEDROOM - DAY Maids quickly place Mamie’s dresses and clothes into boxe CECIL V.O. So we have exactly two hours during the inauguration ceremony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Carter quickly wrap Ike’s trophies in newspaper CECIL V.O. ...to move the old President out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 1950's moving van is parked underneath the North Portic The Housemen place the boxes and furniture into the van. CECIL V.O. ...and move the new President in. The moving pulls away as an identical MOVING VAN pulls up its spot. We hear the distinct Bostonian accent of - JACK V.O. I, John Fitzgerald Kennedy, do solemnly swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire White House staff carries boxes and new furnit

dialogues.speaker: JACK V.O
dialogues.text: That I will faithfully execute the office of President of the United States. RD Warner glances at his watch, starting to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: Forty-eight minutes left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The master bedroom is being set up with a new blue draped four poster bed, Cecil gracefully helps guide it into pla JACK V.O. And will to the best of my ability. INT. WHITE HOUSE - JOHN JOHN’S NURSERY - DAY Cecil opens a box filled with stuffed animals and meticulously places them in the play pen for a baby boy. JACK V.O. Preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution of the United States. INT. WHITE HOUSE - CAROLINE’S ROOM - DAY Cecil delicately sets down a rocking horse next to a cano bed as a maid places pink rosebuds out for a young girl. JACK V.O. So help me God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil looks nervous at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s always scary meetin’ the new President cuz you never know what kinda man he’s gonna be until he moves into that house. (Then) I don’t think he knows either.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the staff is lined up in the Entrance Hall everyon stands at attention, tense. RD Warner wipes his sweaty br as Cecil whispers to Carter.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You nervous? Carter nods, then whispers back.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: I voted for Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Me too. Booker leans in and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: You negroes are a disgrace. The front doors open and in walks JOHN ‘JACK’ KENNEDY, 43 handsome, lean, and his beautiful wife JACKIE, 31, tall, wears a fawn coat and pillow box hat, she’s a touch shy. Jackie holds their 3 month old, JACK, JR, with daughter, CAROLINE, 3, behind them. They are surrounded by many AID Jack flashes an enormous grin, he exudes charm and class.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want to start by saying that I’m thrilled we’re going to be working together over the next four years. Jackie is slightly aloof as she speaks in almost a whispe

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Eight years, Jack. Everyone laughs. The baby, John Jr., starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I bet you all haven’t heard that around the house in a while. The room laughs, Carter turns to Cecil, nods with approva

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kennedy’s tour the house, looking at all the art work with RD Warner, Cecil and Carter in tow. As Jackie looks around, she seems unhappy. She speaks in a light whisper:  46.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Warner, there seem to be very few historic artifacts. There's barely an item here before 1948.

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Eisenhower was concerned about this as well, but as I explained to her, when it comes to redecorating, the budget is very limited. The shy Jackie washes away as her voice gets much louder.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m not talking about redecoration, Mr. Warner, I’m talking about restoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light blue walls are being painted over in a dark gre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rose Garden is packed with landscapers digging it all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks with an exhausted RD Warner and Cecil in tow down the Center Hall pointing at the empty walls.

dialogues.speaker: FADE CUT
dialogues.text: The walls are now covered in a beautiful series of portra of proud American Indians by George Catlin. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - NIGHT Cecil walks out of a new florist shop. Up and down the street, businesses are repainting and upgrading. CECIL V.O. Everywhere I looked, folks were sprucin’ things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks in and sees Gloria repainting the living room Her hair looks like Jackie’s and she wears an A-line dres  47.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What in the Lords name are you doing? Gloria waves her hand with a refined touch.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Restoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in bed reading a book on Addison's disease. Glor reads a Life article about Jackie. She turns to Cecil:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Do you wish I spoke French?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: My goodness, what?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Jackie speaks French.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You are without a doubt the most perfect woman I know. Gloria turns away, looks slightly unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I'm not perfect, I’m just...here.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, honey bear?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ever since Louis has been gone I’ve been feelin’ sort of...restless.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Cuz he’s in jail? She stares at him for a beat, then changes the subject, pointing at his book.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What’s Addison’s Disease?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s a condition that causes fatigue and dizziness. Someone new at the House has it.  48.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Jackie?!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Is it true she’s going to sella White House guide to finance the restoration?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I don’t know nuthing about that. She curls into his chest, talks in sweet-talky voice.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Baby doll?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How many pairs of shoes does Jackie have?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You know I can’t talk about that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You never tell me anything! You're there all day and you can’t even share your whole life with me!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, honey bear...I just can’t talk about it. She rolls over, shuts off the light. Night. He feels guilty, goes back to his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into shot into Jack’s

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: never knew this upset her so much. Then - he book on Addison’s Disease. — MASTER BEDROOM - MORNING the bedroom as a DOCTOR is administering a arm. There are several prescription bottles.  49. Jack's VALET, another Filipino, brushes a jacket with a l brush. Jack grins at Cecil as he takes a series of pills.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was sick so much as a kid that my brothers used to joke if I got bit by a mosquito, the mosquito would surely die. As the Valet puts Jack’s suit jacket on him, Jack clutche his back in pain. Cecil grimaces, feeling Jack’s pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into the Oval Office with a tea set and water Jack is lying on the floor on a heating pad, still in pai Cecil brings him cortisone pills and another glass of wat Jack is mid-conversation with his brother, BOBBY KENNEDY, tough and mean. He sits with his aide, JOHN SEIGENTHALER, slim, idealistic. Seigenthaler holds up a pen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SEIGENTHALER
dialogues.text: This was sent from the ‘National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing’ as a reminder to follow through with your campaign pledge to wipe out federal housing discrimination with one swipe of a pen. Jack takes the pills, then hands the glass back to Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They only sent one?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SEIGENTHALER
dialogues.text: No, sir, ten thousand.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I take it the ‘National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing’ is being sarcastic. Cecil begins to pour a cup of tea, but unlike the last ti we saw him do this, he looks smooth and graceful.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SEIGENTHALER
dialogues.text: They're calling it the ‘Ink for Jack’ campaign.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bobby?  50. Cecil sets the tea in front of Bobby who doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We lose the support we’ll need from Southern Senators on Cuba if we touch civil rights right now. John Seigenthaler eyes Cecil as he pours another cup of t

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you think, John?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SEIGENTHALER
dialogues.text: I think there is a moral imperative to fight against discrimination.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We barely won the election! We don’t have the mandate or the political need to touch contentious social issues right now.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What if there are more negro protests, like those sit-in’s? Cecil slightly flinches at the mention of the sit-ins.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The sit-ins didn’t budge popular opinion. The country doesn’t support civil rights, Jack, I don’t think you should either. Jack ponders it as Cecil walks toward the door with his t

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don’t have time for this right now. I need to use my capital on Kruschev and Castro. Jack looks over at Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Detente abroad trumps detente at home. Bobby slightly grins, he likes to win.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I doubt we’ll even see anymore civil unrest. Cecil glances at Bobby...he hopes that he’s right.  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Carol are in the tiny headquarters of the ‘Cong of Racial Equality’. It has a pre-hippy, new age vibe. Th sit with JAMES FARMER, 41, black, theatrical voice.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FARMER
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with Boynton V. Virginia? They shake their heads, no. JAMES FARMER (CONT’D) It outlawed segregation in bus terminals, but the law has never been enforced.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: So you're going to ride busses into the deep south to confront the law?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FARMER
dialogues.text: Exactly. We expect to be beaten, maybe even murdered, but we will exercise our legal rights. Louis and Carol exchange glances, nervous, but Carol nods

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We want to be a part of it. James Farmer smiles at his fellow warriors.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FARMER
dialogues.text: Are you two together? Before Louis can answer, Carol quickly responds:

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, we're just friends. Louis looks disappointed, but he mutters.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're just friends. James Farmer knows that Louis was hoping otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES FARMER
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard the Freedom Ride.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a tuxedo, Jack stands in front of several hundred elegant guests seated in chairs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: When Jackie told me she wanted to use the White House as a platform for the arts, I knew it was a good idea because I do what Jackie says. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The last time our esteemed guest Pablo Caslas played in the White House was fifty-seven years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great musician, PABLO CASALS, 85, wise, finishes a gl of water, whispers to Cecil in his Spanish accent.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO CASLAS
dialogues.text: After 81 years of playing, you know what always surprises me?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What, Sr. Caslas?

dialogues.speaker: PABLO CASLAS
dialogues.text: That I still get nervous. He hands him the glass of water. Then - PABLO CASLAS (CONT’D) Do you find it difficult being oppressed in your own home land? Cecil doesn’t know what to say, stunned. Just then, the c in the East Room applauds. Freddie opens the door for Cas who enters the room. Cecil sits next to Booker and Carter

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: What did he say to you? Cecil looks at him for a beat. Then -

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Nuthin’.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding his violoncello, Casals gives the President a sli head bow, Jack nods back. Then, he begins Mendelssohn's T in D Minor. We hear the most beautiful music play into... EXT. ALABAMA —- COUNTRY ROAD - NIGHT A Greyhound bus drives down a dark country road in Alabam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen Freedom Riders are on the bus with a few JOURNALI white. Every black Freedom Rider sits next to a white one The mood is fairly relaxed. Louis sits toward the back, speaking to a JOURNALIST. Carol is asleep a few seats ove

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Are you riding this bus to show that the negro is equal to the white man?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: No, sir. We do not seek equality with the white man. We want us both to be raised up. The bus slows down, pulling into a bus station. Everyone up alert as they see the bus station is completely EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why isn’t anybody here? A MOB of white people with chains and bats STORM out from behind the bus station. Louis screams at the driver -

dialogues.speaker: DRIVE
dialogues.text: The Freedom Bus takes off down the highway, but a row of and trucks pull out from behind the bus station. An ambus GUNSHOTS blare out that hit the tires. The bus SKIDS back forth, then skids onto a dirt embankment and comes to a s The cars catch up and a mob of 100 WHITE MEN jump out and start SMASHING the bus windows with bricks and chains. All of the Freedom Riders drop to the center aisle of the as glass shards fly on top of them. Then - A MOLOTOV COCK flies into the back window setting the back on FIRE!  54. The Freedom Riders push to the front of the bus and try t open the front door, but the MOB is outside PUSHING it sh A white Freedom Rider at the bus door, ELI COWLING, pulls a gun. The other Freedom Riders look stunned as he points gun toward the mob through the glass door. The mob backs The door flies open as Eli Cowling holds up a badge.

dialogues.speaker: ELI COWLING
dialogues.text: Let these people off or some of you are going to die! The crowd backs away even more. All the Freedom Riders stumble out of the bus, coughing and gasping for air. The THE BUS EXPLODES! The Freedom Riders fall to the ground a the mob begins to circle in them. One of them CLUBS Louis the head as the cello music comes to a passionate conclus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The concert over, Caslas shakes hands with the President. Cecil hurries over with cocktails, Caslas whispers to Jac

dialogues.speaker: PABLO CASLAS
dialogues.text: Remember all those people out there who need freedom. Jack and Cecil are both taken by his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in the upstairs kitchen taking notes. He writes ‘20 guests, 10 servers, Truman service.’ Then, he hears: BANGING at the end of the hall. He sticks his head out to Bobby Kennedy pounding on Jack’s bedroom door, he’s furio

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jack! Get up! The door opens, a sleepy Jack sticks his head out

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The Freedom Bus was blown up in Alabama. Jack's face drops in shock, Cecil’s in horror.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are they dead?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We don’t know, it hasn’t been confirmed. Governor Patterson won't return my calls.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I‘ll cut Patterson’s balls off! Bobby enters the room as Jack slams the door. Cecil stare forward in horror. CECIL V.O. I didn’t know if my son was dead or alive. Then - he feels a tug at his pants, a just woken up 4 yea old Caroline Kennedy holds a children’s book.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Cecil, will you read me a book? Cecil instantly regains his composure.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Of course, Miss Caroline. She walks him to a table in the kitchen. Caroline sits on lap and opens ‘Madeline’s Rescue’. There’s a picture of a spooky looking mansion that looks like the White House.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘In an old house in Paris that was covered in vines, lived 12 little girls in two straight lines.’

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Like me and John John.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Exactly. (Back to the book) “The smallest one was Madeline. She was not afraid of mice.” Caroline beams as Cecil tries to not cry, so scared for h son. He puts his arm around Caroline as he continues...

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘She loved winter, snow and ice.’  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Gloria are on the couch watching Jackie’s White House tour on the TV. They’re tense, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: ‘'May none but wise men ever rule under this roof.’ It was Franklin Roosevelt who loved that prayer and had it put on the mantlepiece.’' The phone rings! They jump up as Cecil quickly answers it

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Hello? His entire body slumps in relief as hears: LOUIS V.O. I'm in Mississippi. Gloria starts to tear up, knowing her son is alive.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I thought you were in Alabama? LOUIS V.O. We spent two weeks in jail there, now we’re in Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Please come home. Please. Just for a little while. A few days. Please. LOUIS V.O. That's going to be difficult under the present circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandages and bruised, Louis is in a blue prison uniform calling from the pay phone. The prison looks like hell.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I've been detained by the local authorities.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: For how long?  57.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Three months. When I get out, I’m going to take another Freedom Ride.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Why, Louis?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Because it is my right to ride that bus. That is my legal right and I will exercise my rights as an American citizen!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: They're going to kill you. At some point you gonna get killed.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
