dialogues.text: They're gonna have to kill me, Dad, because I’‘ll never stop. Cecil’s eyes fill with tears, so scared for Louis.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: All we do is worry about you. Come home, son, please, just for a little while. We miss you so much.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Dad, but I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I’m a Freedom Rider. He hangs up the phone on his father.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Is he comin’ home? Cecil shakes his head, no, a look of painful defeat on bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil lies awake in bed, starring up at the ceiling. CECIL V.O. I was scared all the time... Gloria lies awake on her side, she’s not sleeping either.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--but it was a scary time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RD Warner is speaking to all the BUTLERS and several MAID

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: If Cuba launches a missile attack on the capital, your number one priority is to get the First Family out of the house first. Several people nod. Terrified looks are exchanged. CECIL V.O. Everyday we thought might be our last...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several staff walk through the security gate, all are ten CECIL V.O. ..-but everyday we still came to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is preparing a sandwich. CECIL V.O. If the President was gonna prevent our nuclear destruction, some one was gonna have to feed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil passes the Red Room and sees one of the maids cryin He immediately gives her a warm hug.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Everything is gonna be fine, Tanya, no one’s gonna get hurt. She nods as she continues to cry, so scared. CECIL V.O. I wasn’t sure we’d make it, but those Kennedy boys were real smart.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booker reads a copy of the Washington Post with the headl ‘REDS AGREE TO SCRAP BASES IN CUBA’. Carter has a huge sm

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: That was without a doubt the worst two weeks of my entire life. Booker nods, but Cecil still looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, Cecil? We made it. Cecil tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil lies awake in bed again, Gloria awake on her side. CECIL V.O. But for us, the fear was never gonna go away.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: Black & White archival footage of black children and teen being hosed down in the streets by police and firemen as barking dogs snap at them. NEWSCAST V.O. Protests in Birmingham, Alabama turned violent this morning as police turned fire hoses on the protestors, most of them children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Bobby and Jackie watch the news footage, they look horrified. Cecil and Booker stand against the back wall, struggling to not appear upset. Jack looks deeply trouble

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what country I’m looking at. Cecil peeks out over Jack’s shoulder, looking for Louis.  60. EXT. BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA — DAY Louis is sprayed with a fire hose, jammed against a brick wall. Carol clutches a tree as water drills into her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil stares at the TV screen, barely able to hide his fe He sees Jack staring at him, he quickly looks forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in the Lincoln Bedroom dusting off the dark wood desk. He is about to walk out when something catches his He walks back to Lincoln’s desk and cleans off a small sp

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Do you ever see the ghost? Surprised, Cecil turns around to see Jack in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, Mr. President, I’ve never seen Lincoln’s ghost.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They say he still haunts this room.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I’ve heard that as well, but I don’t know anyone who’s seen him. Jack Kennedy takes a step forward, lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I know your son is a Freedom Rider. Cecil’s face drops.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s in prison in Birmingham right now with Martin Luther King.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm guessing he’s beat up, but from his record, he must be used to it. He’s been arrested 16 times in the last two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Dr. King is supposed to be a great man, but I don’t understand what he’s done to my son.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about your job, Cecil, I‘ll keep this quiet.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. President, I don’t want to lose my job...but I just don’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Neither do I. (Then) But those kids... His voice trails off, this is hard for him to say.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...those kids have changed my heart, Cecil... Tears form in Jack’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...they’ve changed my heart.
Jack sits in front of a TV news camera in the Oval Office Bobby stands nearby, watching his brother address the nat

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: One hundred years of delay have passed since President Lincoln freed the slaves, yet their heirs, their grandsons, are not fully free from the bonds of injustice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis is in a prison cell reading the speech in a newspap A small look of pride, his work is starting to pay off. JACK V.O. Next week I shall ask the Congress to enact legislation giving all Americans the right to be served in facilities open to the public.  62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is in a hotel room for ‘blacks only’ with five brui Freedom Riders watching the speech.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: This seems to me to be an elementary right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small smile forms on Bobby’s face as his brother finish his historic address. Bobby has been transformed as well.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A great change is at hand, and our task, our obligation, is to make that revolution, that change...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Butlers all watch the speech on a TV.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: .+-peaceful and constructive for all. Everyone applauds, except for Cecil who looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil still looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I knew this would embolden those kids. Their rebellion was workin’ and there was no way they were gonna stop now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Carter help out the dishwashers wash the china. Everyone is energized except for Cecil who looks distract CECIL V.O. I worried all the time that someone was gonna get killed. Every day I expected the call and I couldn’t think about nuthin’ else.  63. A Polk plate slips through Cecil’s fingers and SHATTERS o the floor. Cecil stares at the destroyed plate in mild sh

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It...it just slipped.

dialogues.speaker: DISHWASHER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: It ain’t nuthin’. But Cecil looks really upset at himself. Then Booker walk into the room, his face is ashen.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you? It’s just a plate. Booker can’t speak, clearly shaken about something else.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, Booker? Booker looks at the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: The President’s been shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flag outside of the White House is lowered to half ma CECIL V.O. We laid him in state in the exact same manner as Abraham Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Booker place black webbing over the windows, th room has been completely transformed into a mausoleum. MILITARY GUARDS bring in the flag draped coffin and place on the alter covered in black. Jackie and Bobby follow, s still wears her pink skirt covered in Jack's blood.

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy, would you like me to have a change of clothes brought down? Jackie shakes her head, no. Defiant.  64.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I want them to see, I want them all to see what they did to my husband. Cecil stares at the coffin, devastated with grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in her bloodied skirt, Jackie wanders the hall look at the paintings as she clutches one of her husband's tie Cecil gingerly walks over to her as she mutters:

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: So now he is a legend, when he would have preferred to be a man.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do for you, Mrs. Kennedy? Please tell me how can I help you. She smiles at Cecil, holds out the tie for him.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy, I can’t take that.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Please, Cecil, he’d want you to have it, Jack was very fond of you. He takes the tie.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I will always treasure it. She touches his face, then continues strolling down the h looks almost like a ghost. Cecil walks the other directio As he passes the Lincoln Bedroom he hears Bobby sobbing:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why!? Why, God? Why!? Cecil stares at the door clutching President Kennedy's ti he can’t help it as the tears fall down his face.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil lies in bed in his tux, the tie still in his hand. Gloria is clutched in his arms, face red from crying. The lie there in silence. Then Cecil slowly starts to tell he

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: She's very witty. Most people don’t know that, but she’s very witty and sometimes she can be silly. She’s very relaxed and playful around the house, but when she’s in public she transforms into a different person.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: That’s when she becomes more aloof, and mysterious, but always elegant. She’s very complex...and beautiful...and wonderful. (Turns to her) What else do you want to know about Jackie? I'll tell you anything you want to know. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Cecil, Carter, Booker and Freddie Fallows are out on the course watching Booker miss a long put. They yell, ‘OHHHH

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: The white man prevented you from hitting your shot!

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: You know he did! They all laugh as they stroll to the next hole.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to have a fund-raiser at church next month for all those kids in Mississippi trying to register black folk. You bloods should come down.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: ‘Black’ folk?  66.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: That's right, ace boon coon, we ain’t no negroes no mo’!

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: I’ll go. I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: What about you two Tom’s? Those kids are putting it on the line.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. What about you, Mr. Fallows?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: I will be in the Bahamas, celebrating my retirement. (Then) Congratulations, Carter, you are going to be the new Maitre d. The Butlers are stunned, Cecil beams at Carter.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s time for me to move on, gentleman, I’m getting old.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: But you gonna miss out on all the fun with LBJ! They all laugh with clear sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYNDON JOHNSON, 55, gray haired with glasses, fiery, mani sits on the toilet with his pants at his ankles surrounde four queasy staff members. Cecil is jammed in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: You sorry sap ass motherfuckers gotta realize that the nigger ain’t gonna take it no more! This entire country is a tinderbox, ya see, a goddamn tinderbox of nigger rage just waitin’ to explode!  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ screams at Cecil in the Queens Room:

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Next time there is a light on in an empty room, I will fire every sorry son of a bitch in this house. I mean it, Cecil, I‘’1l go back to Texas and run the country froma dirt shack if I have to! Is that what you want?!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, sir. Cecil flicks off the light switch. LBJ instantly flips to gregarious, jovial southerner as he slaps Cecil on the ba

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Now that’s what I’m talkin’ about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Booker are playing cards, both drinking coffee. Carter reads a newspaper, looks at his watch, it’s 3am.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Does the man ever sleep? In walks LBJ’s wife, LADY BIRD, sweet and private, she sp in an elegant Texan accent. They both immediately stand u

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What can we do for you, Mrs. Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD
dialogues.text: I just feel terrible about Lyndon’'s schedule. He’s been staying up all night long trying to get this bill passed, and y'all are stuck here.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: We don’t mind at all, Mrs. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD
dialogues.text: I was thinking you could have some food pre-made for Lyndon that he’d heat up himself if he wants to eat in the middle of the night.  68.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you how much we appreciate the gesture, Mrs. Johnson, but no President will ever serve himself as long as we are the White House butlers.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Booker emphatically nods with pride.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: We serve the President, so that the President can serve the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into the Treaty Room carrying a tray with a silver lid. LBJ is seated at the desk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I know it’s three in the morning, Senator, but I actually wasn’t calling for you, I wanted to speak to your wife. (The voice responds) Then you'll just have to wake her up now, won’t you. He motions for Cecil to serve him. Cecil elaborately sets down a place mat, a gold fork, knife and spoon.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Good morning, Barbara, this is your President speaking, I sure hope I didn’t wake you. Cecil places a large plate of green beans in front of LBJ covers the mouth piece, asks Cecil:

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These canned? Cecil nods. LBJ gives him a pleased wink.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The reason why I’m calling so late is your husband is wavering on signing Kennedy's Civil Rights Bill, and the American negra’ needs your husband’s support.  69. Cecil sets down a tapioca pudding and plate of pancakes n to the green beans, LBJ grins at his bizarre feast.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, until he agrees to vote for this bill, I’m gonna have to call you every night at three in the morning, and if he doesn’t vote with me, well, I may just keep on calling for the next year or two to tell you how disappointed I am. As Cecil walks out, he glances at LBJ who digs in to the green bean. Cecil looks baffled by LBJ. CECIL V.O. I never before seen a man who said ‘nigger’ so much, work so hard to help negroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is hand washing his socks in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Sometimes people grow up one way, but then they can become someone else, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butlers are in the pantry restocking the shelf with glasses and cups. They all look exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve had a full night’s sleep in a year. Cecil and Carter nod in agreement. Then, Booker’s face dr in amazement as he sees something. Carter sees what Booke sees, he too is stunned. Carter taps Cecil who jumps up. They stare forward in quiet shock at the end of the pantr Booker’s eyes fill with tears. Standing across from them MARTIN LUTHER KING. Only 35, King is very handsome with a rare ability to exu warmth and dignity at the same time.  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry to disturb you, gentleman, but I wanted to meet you all. I’m Martin. He steps forward and holds out his hand to Booker.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: This is the greatest honor of my life, Dr. King. Martin Luther King smiles, he’s very approachable.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: The honor is all mine. He shakes hands with Carter who is also beaming. Cecil sh his hand last, he is formal, a touch cool.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you, Dr. King. King grins at their tuxedos.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: My, oh, my, y'all look just superb. Cecil can’t help it as a tiny smile creeps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ sits across from MLK, each flanked by their aides. Ce stands nearby underneath a magnolia tree.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: Your success with the Civil Rights Bill is greatly appreciated within the negro community, Mr. President. A tiny drop of water FALLS from the magnolia tree and lan on the back of Cecil’s neck. It sends shivers down his sp but he stands perfectly still, doesn’t move. MARTIN LUTHER KING (CONT’D) No President has done more for the negro since Abraham Lincoln freed us from chains. LBJ is beaming, feels great about what he accomplished. MARTIN LUTHER KING (CONT’D) But it’s not enough.  71. LBJ’s smile drops. Cecil glances over in surprise. CECIL V.O. That was the first time I ever started really listenin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is wringing his socks out.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, I’d hear things from time to time, but I would never listen.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: So why’d you start now?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A negro was tellin’ the President of the United States that a five course meal ain’t good enough, he wants all eight courses. I never heard nuthin’ like it in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Luther King lights into LBJ:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: Only 5% of the negroes in Mississippi are registered to vote, 11% in Alabama. We desperately need a Voting Rights Bill if we’re going to insure we are no longer blocked from Southern voting booths. Cecil stares forward in stunned amazement.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Goddamit, King! You know how many bridges I had to promise to get the last bill passed! I owe every two bit Congressman three bridges, a park and a fuckin’ airport. I spent eight months grabbing all these dumb sons-a-bitches by the balls and I got no more balls to grab, Dr. King, I used up all my negra’ capital!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: On the bridges and the balls.  72.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: That's right, Dr. King. Now y'all are just gonna have to cool down for a little while. Another drop of water falls from the tree on to Cecil’s n he shuts his eyes in pain. Chinese water torture.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: I should warn you, Mr. President, that I’ve got people in the streets down South right now trying to register the negro vote. Cecil’s eyes flicker in concern. MARTIN LUTHER KING (CONT’D) My guess is that it’s going to go from cool to hot very fast.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Where? Cecil glances over at King right as a drop forms above hi

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: Selma. The drop falls... INT. REGISTRAR’S OFFICE - NIGHT A black male APPLICANT, 50’s, is in a REGISTRAR OFFICE, b escorted by Louis. The REGISTRAR, snide, reads a question

dialogues.speaker: REGISTRAR
dialogues.text: If the President does not wish to sign a bill, how many days is he allowed in which to return it to Congress for reconsideration? The black applicant looks at him, baffled. The Registrar stamps the word ‘REJECTED’ on his application. Louis shak his head in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lively party is going down in the basement of the Gains House. Cecil serves all his friends martinis and appetize  73.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: My niece went to register to vote in Georgia and they made her wait for hours. Then when she finally got in, she had to take a test with all sort of crazy questions. Stuff only an expert would know.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: And the white folks are asked who the first president was. Cecil continues to serve, he looks like he’s not listenin

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: And then those three kids were killed in Mississippi registering black folk. Cecil tries to hide his fear at this news.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: The only reason why the President sent the FBI is cuz two of them were white. Everyone nods, except for Cecil. Gloria turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Shouldn't the President do more to pass a voting bill?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: President Johnson just passed the greatest piece of civil rights legislation since Lincoln freed the slaves, it’s going to be very difficult to pass another bill anytime soon. Most of the room nods in agreement, when Cecil speaks the listen. He holds up a tray of cocktails to lighten the mo

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now how about some more spirits while we wait? They all smile as they grab another drink. Gloria stares Cecil, it’s clear she disagrees with him.  74. INT. BROWN’S CHAPEL - SELMA, ALABAMA — NIGHT Louis and Carol are with a huge crowd in the pews. They listen to a 39 year old black speaker in a black suit, sk tie and browline glasses. His name is MALCOLM xX.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM X
dialogues.text: Back during slavery, there were two kinds of negroes, there was the house negro and the field negro. The house negro lived better than the field negro. He ate better, he dressed better, and he lived right up next to his master. Louis stares at Malcolm X, taken by what he’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil stands in front of the family in his White House Tu for the first time. 14 year old Louis looks at him, uneas INT. BROWN’S CHAPEL - SELMA, ALABAMA - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM X
dialogues.text: Then you had the field negro who hated the master because they caught hell and felt the sting of the lash. Louis starts to nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freedom Bus burns as Louis gets clubbed in the head. INT. BROWN’S CHAPEL - SELMA, ALABAMA - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM X
dialogues.text: And today you still have house negroes and field negroes! The audience applauds as Louis nods in agreement.  75. MALCOLM X (CONT’D) The same old slave masters today have house negroes, who are nothing more than 20th century Uncle Tom’s keeping us passive in non-violence. That’s Uncle Tom making you non- violent, so you suffer peacefully. Louis’ face drops, he no longer likes this speech. MALCOLM X (CONT’D) Dr. King came to Selma with his message of non-violence and I think the white people of Selma would do well to listen to Dr. King, before the field negro comes along and does things another way. The crowd breaks out in applause, but Louis looks pissed. glances at Carol who has a grin on her face. Louis does n like what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ALLEY WAY
dialogues.text: Louis and Carol are walking down a dark alley, he looks disturbed, unsure of what to make of Malcolm X. Carol als looks disturbed, but she’s now unsure of what to make of Just then - a GUNSHOT rings through the night. Louis instinctually grabs Carol and shoves her up against a wal their faces inches apart from each other. Then - She grabs his face and KISSES him on the mouth. Their mou and arms inner-twine as they furiously make out in the al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria walks down the stairs and finds Cecil standing in living room, he holds up a personal check.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What is this? Gloria cringes, knows that she’s been caught.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Have you been sending Louis money?  76.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He needs it.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna pay for him to kill himself. Cecil rips the check up.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he wants to get thrown in jail then he can pay his own way! Cecil storms up the stairs. Gloria watches him go, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Carol lay naked under bed covers in a dank mote room. Louis looks quietly content, but Carol is all busin

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We're losing the press. Louis doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're losing the momentum. King is in prison and no one cares, something’s got to happen, we got to make something happen. He turns to her:

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Marry me. Silence. She doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every time I’m rottin’ in jail, all I think about is you. You keep me sane in this insane world. I want you to be my wife.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I've hated myself since before I was born. How am I supposed to know how to love you? Louis stares at her for a beat. Then -  77.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: If I can wait out Jim Crow, I can wait out you. She tries not to smile, but she clearly liked the answer. EXT. DALLAS COURTHOUSE - SELMA, ALABAMA —- DAY Hundreds of black protestors are marching through downtow Selma toward the courthouse. As always, crowds of whites lined up on the sidewalks screaming and booing at them. Police in riot gear stand between the whites and blacks. Louis and Carol march with the crowd. Carol looks worried she whispers to Louis in hushed fury.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: There’s no press here, we’re losing this thing. We are losin’! She turns to him, an anger building deep in her soul.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You understand me, you stupid nigger, we're gonna lose Selma! SHERIFF JIM CLARK, fat, jabs his nightstick into Louis ri

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF JIM CLARK
dialogues.text: Get in the middle of the street. Carol grabs the nightstick and stares at the Sheriff. SHERIFF JIM CLARK (CONT’D) What in the hell do you think ya doin’? Carol lifts her fist and PUNCHES Sheriff Clark right in t face. Totally blind sided, he falls over. Louis looks terrified and grabs Carol, but she shoves him off, jumps on top of the Sheriff and PUNCHES him again. A again. And again. And again. And again. Three cops finally jump on top of her and start beating h with their nightsticks. A PHOTOGRAPHER frantically shoots pictures of the beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a packed black church, a PASTOR holds up a copy of the Times with a photo of Carol getting beat on the front pag  78.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning these brave men, women and children in Selma are going to begin a march to Montgomery and we need to give them all the support we can! Hats are being passed around where people toss in their dollar bills and change. Booker and his wife, THELMA, pre sit in the pews next to Carter and his wife, SOPHIE, shy.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever change you’ve got, put it in the till because every dollar is goin’ to Selma! Gloria sneaks into the back of the church. She takes out thick roll of one dollar bills and places it in a hat.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now let us pray for them. (Shuts his eyes) Oh, dear lord, protect these brave men and women as they march for freedom. No one is praying harder than Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Protect them as they seek to protect us.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: Black & white news footage of the black protestors gettin clubbed by a militia on the Edmund Pettus bridge. NEWSCAST V.O. ‘The Alabama State Gaurd brutally suppressed a march from Selma to Montgomery today in what has been dubbed ‘Bloody Sunday.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ watches the newscast on three separate televisions at same time. Lady Bird watches with him, horrified. Cecil stands behind him, trying to find his son on TV.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis is on the ground coughing from tear gas as riot pol and horses trample everywhere around him. A bandaged Caro lies on top of a young teenage girl, protecting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil looks terrified, but LBJ is stoic as the news foota reflects off his glasses, it effects him on a deep level.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: The South is never gonna vote Democratic again. Cecil looks at him, not sure what he means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ stands at the lectern in Congress addressing the Sena the House of Representatives and the country:

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Every American citizen must have an equal right to vote. Yet the harsh fact is that in many places in this country men and women are kept from voting because they are Negroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil, Booker and Carter watch the speech in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: The negro is given a test. He may be asked to recite the entire Constitution, or explain the most complex provisions of State law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria watches alone, enthralled...she’s part of this now

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: And even a college degree cannot be used to prove that he can read and write. For the fact is that the only way to pass these barriers is to show a white skin.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, Carol and Martin Luther King are crammed in a room full of beaten up Selma protestors. Everyone is bandaged bruised as they watch the speech.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: On Wednesday, I will send to Congress a law designed to eliminate illegal barriers to the right to vote. The room is beaming, several hugs and pats on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ gets worked up as he speaks deep from his heart:

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: What happened in Selma is part of a far larger movement which reaches into every section and State of America. Their cause must be our cause too. Because it's not just Negroes, but really it's all of us who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we shall overcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The protestors cheer in celebration, Louis and Carol hug joy. The only person not cheering is Martin Luther King because his face is covered in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil watches LBJ on the TV, taken by what he’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: The real hero of this struggle is the American negro. His actions and protests have awakened the conscience of this nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s those kids in Selma, they did this. They made this happen. A tiny smile forms on Cecil’s face.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (FROM THE TV)
dialogues.text: His demonstrations have been designed to call attention to injustice, designed to provoke change, designed to stir reform. For the first time, Cecil looks truly proud of his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is in awe at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: The greatest politician of our time said he could never pass that bill, and then because of my son and his friends, the Voting Rights Act of 1964 was passed. (Then ) Ain't that somethin’. INT. WHITE HOUSE - RD WARNER’S OFFICE - DAY Cecil sits across from the Chief Usher, RD Warner. Cecil nervous, gripping his sweaty palms.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Since the black staff does just as much work as the white staff, I believe our salaries should reflect our service.

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: ‘Black’ staff?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I also feel that we should have opportunities at advancement. Black houseman are never promoted to the engineer's office. RD Warner stares at Cecil for a long beat. Then -—  82.

dialogues.speaker: RD WARNER
dialogues.text: You're very well liked here, Cecil, but if you’re unhappy with your salary or position, than I suggest you seek employment elsewhere. Cecil looks surprised that he got such a hard rebuke, but quickly covers it up with a warm, but defeated smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Luther King is in his hotel room seated across fro his various associates and aides. Louis sits across from They are watching footage of the Vietnam War on televisio

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCAST
dialogues.text: “US Casualties are on the rise in Vietnam, giving fuel to critics who say there is no end in sight for what has become a bloody war.” Martin Luther King shakes his head, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: President Johnson may have a big heart, but he is making a tragic error in Vietnam. Everyone nods their heads in agreement. MARTIN LUTHER KING (CONT’D) How many of your parents support the war? Almost all of them raise their hands. MARTIN LUTHER KING (CONT’D) That’s why we’ve got to keep speaking out against it. (To Louis) Why do your parents support it?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We haven't spoken about it specifically, I just know they do.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: What does your dad do? Louis looks embarrassed to say.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: He’s a butler.  83.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. The black domestic. They serve a great role in our history.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: The black domestic defies racial stereotypes by being hardworking and trustworthy. He slowly breaks down racial hatreds by the example of his strong work ethic and dignified character. (Then) So even though we perceive the butler as being subservient, they are in many ways subversive without even knowing it. Louis stares at him, never thought about his dad in this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis walks out of the Lorraine Motel, he is deep in thou effected by what MLK said about his father. Then - The sounds of GUNSHOTS explode in the air. Louis drops to knees for cover. He looks up and sees King’s aides standi over a man lying on the balcony. They point to roof tops across the way. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - NIGHT Thousands of people are in the streets in Cecil’s neighborhood. People are crying, screaming in anger. A furious black man picks up a trash can and throws it in store window, glass shatters everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of NATIONAL GUARDSMEN line up in front of the Wh House in full riot gear. Shields and clubs ready for acti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in his Tuxedo, Cecil drives his car down a dark str it’s dark and quiet, almost eerie. On the radio -  84.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSCAST
dialogues.text: “Riots have broken out in DC, fueled by anger over the assassination of Martin Luth--” Cecil hits the brakes as THREE BLACK MAN dart out in the street in front of him, running from a liquor store. BOOM!!! The store EXPLODES! Cecil’s car FLIPS onto it’s s EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - NIGHT The riot has tripled in size. Stores are on fire as windo are smashed and buildings set on fire. All the renovation and upgrades of the last decade destroyed in minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil squirms out of the passenger side window of his car bleeding at his temples. He starts walking down the stree A MOB of hundreds of black men are coming toward him. Gun shots are fired into the air as the mob breaks windows. Police sirens whirl as a RIOT SQUAD pulls up at the end o the block. The RIOTERS march toward the riot police with Cecil directly in between. He doesn’t know which way to g Tear gas is volleyed through the air and lands in the mid of the rioters. Cecil starts coughing from the tear gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man smashes windows with a baseball bat as fires rage around him. It is violent and aggressive as other LOOTERS back away from him. He turns around as we see it’s - Louis. There is a dark anger in his eyes, transformed by rage. Carol hurries over to him, puts her arms around him

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I’m not taking it no mo’, baby...I’m not taking it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OTIS PLACE
dialogues.text: Cecil walks up his block, dabbing a handkerchief on his forehead. People stare at the fires that consume the city  85. Gloria waits on the balcony with Gina and Elroy who’s 18 She runs into the street and gives Cecil a huge bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I'm okay, honey bear, I’m alright. Elroy stares at the fires with anger and frustration.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Why are they setting their own neighborhood on fire?!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: They’re angry, Elroy.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It’s happening all over the country. They all stare out at the fires that engulf Washington DC

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: America is burning for Martin Luther King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil drives his tattered car through the war torn street Burnt buildings, rubble everywhere, military police in ta There is a sadness in him at the ruins of his neighborhoo CECIL V.O. Three months later, Bobby Kennedy was assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil gets out of his car and walks toward the White Hous CECIL V.O. Seemed like riots were breaking out everyday. They even had one in Chicago during the Democratic Convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of protestors stand outside the back gate of the White House entrance. They are mostly white students and HIPPIES dressed in colorful tie-dye clothes and beads.  86. CECIL V.O. And now the white kids were just as angry as the black kids. Holding up Anti-Vietnam War signs, they scream at Cecil a pushes his way through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTORS
dialogues.text: How can you work there?!/You’re just a nigger to them!/LBJ is a baby killer! Cecil maintains his warm smile as the Protestors shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butlers and housemen prepare the State Dining Room. T Protestors outside the White House are heard:

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: -A Maid makes a bed, glancing toward the window. PROTESTORS V.O.

dialogues.speaker: YOU KILLED TODAY
dialogues.text: -A Calligrapher writes out an invitation, distracted. PROTESTORS V.O. (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: YOU KILLED TODAY
dialogues.text: -The Florist designs a new arrangement, she looks upset. PROTESTORS V.O. (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ stares out the window at the furious protestors. PROTESTORS V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LBJ looks like a worn out old man, tired, drained, but mo defeated. Cecil stands behind him, sets down a can of Fre

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I brought you a Fresca, Mr. President. LBJ looks back at him, smiles through his sadness.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Thank you, Cecil. He takes a huge swig, it makes him feel a little better.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s your boy doing? Cecil doesn’t answer immediately, tough to talk about Lou

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Mr. President. Sometimes I feel like we’re living in two different worlds. All I want is for him to be safe, but no matter what I say, he always gets so angry at me. The Protestors get even louder:

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: He keeps telling me that I don’t understand him...and maybe he’s right. Maybe I just don’t understand him anymore. LBJ looks at Cecil with a deep pain. He feels the same wa about the country.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: Sometimes it’s hard to be a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is ironing a pair of black pants.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: Were you sad that LBJ didn’t run for a second term?  88. Cecil looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: How much more time do we have? I don’t want to be late.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: We've got a few more hours. (Then) Were you sad to see him go?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I’m always sad when the First Family leaves. Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moving van is parked as Housemen carry LBJ'’s boxes t Right after a Houseman shuts the van door, it takes off. CECIL V.O. But I was also secretly excited that an old friend was comin’ back. An identical moving van immediately pulls up in its place hear the voice of the new President: RICHARD V.O. I, Richard Milhous Nixon, do solemnly swear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Nixon and his wife, PAT NIXON, 56, walk down the Center Hall flanked by staff and RD Warner. She is poised lean with a perfect blond coif. Pat is quiet, but not col They are taking a tour of their new living quarters led b Warner. He is flanked by a few aides and the Nixon daught TRICIA, 22, petite blond and JULIE, 20, brunette. Nixon smiles as he gives Cecil his signature Victory salu Cecil gives it back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is in the kitchen, rolling dough for dinner. She l unhappy, perhaps something is missing from her life. Just then, there is a knock at the door. She opens it to see -  89. Louis and Carol. They both have afros and wear black pant and black leather jackets, a militant ‘black power’ look.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Ma. Gloria tears up at the site of her son, so excited to see him. She flings open the door and gives him a huge hug.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma, I want you to meet my fiance, Carol Blue. Gloria's eyes light up. She screams:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: The dear lord has finally answered my prayers! She throws her arms around Carol, embracing her in a big

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire family is having dinner along with several neighbors, including Gina and Elroy, who is dressed in a uniform. An impromptu welcome home party. There is a tension in the air as no one knows what to mak Louis and Carol’s ‘black power’ look. Cecil is particular put off. Louis glances at Elroy, hates his Navy uniform.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You goin’ to Vietnam?

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Gina puts her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: We all so proud. Everyone nods. Louis and Carol glance at each other, then back to their food, biting their tongues. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So, Carol, I have all sorts of cooking supplies you can have when you two move in together.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Gains, but I don’t cook.  90.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The sisters in our political organization refuse to partake in traditional gender roles. This makes Gloria feel a little self conscious.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s very...unique.

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: What’s your political organization called?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The Black Panther Party. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We promote Black Power through pride in our African heritage as expressed in the teachings and self discipline of Brothers Huey Newton and Bobby Seale.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We provide free breakfast for children, free medical clinics, and free self defense classes.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Self defense classes?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We ain’t gonna get beat no mo’. This lands like a hammer. The room looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: That reminds me of a movie I just saw that you might like. ‘In the Heat of the Night’. Sidney Poitier plays a cop that goes Sout--

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I won’t see anything with Sidney Poitier.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Sidney Poitier is the white man’s fantasy of what he wants the black to be. Well behaved with no sense of his manhood as a sexual being.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: But his movies have him fighting for equal rights.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Only in a way that is acceptable to the white status quo. He earns the white man’s respect with false dignity instead of fighting against the immorality of his degradation. (Then) And the brother can’t act. Carol and him laugh. Cecil looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: He won the Academy Award...he’s broken barriers for our people.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: By being white, by acting white. Sidney Poitier is nothing but a rich Uncle Tom. Cecil jumps to his feet and screams:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Honey!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: HE’S AN UNCLE TOM! Cecil SMASHES a plate.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I’M SORRY, BUTLER! I DIDN’T MEAN TO

dialogues.speaker: MAKE FUN OF YO HERO
dialogues.text: Gloria SLAPS Louis across the face. Hard. Gina gasps.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Never disrespect your father in this house. NEVER! Everything you have is because of him. Everything! Your father is a saint and you will treat him with respect! Silence. Then, Louis laughs, nods to Carol to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Shit, alright. I’m gone. You negroes be good, while me and my girl get y'all some mo’ rights.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: So long, pops.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Just get out. Louis and Carol turn around and walk out of the devastate room. Cecil stares at them, fuming in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks down a hall with a tray of tea, the anger and bitterness still plastered across his face. Right when he turns into the room, his face instantly fli to his pleasant smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil brings in a tea for Nixon who is deep in conversati with his two closest advisors - BOB HALDEMAN, 44, crew cu intense, and JOHN EHRLICHMAN, 45, balding, boy scout face

dialogues.speaker: HALDEMAN
dialogues.text: We think the time calls for a period of benign neglect. Cecil pours tea for Nixon.  93.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Benign neglect?

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: The polls overwhelmingly show white voters are tired of the race issue and feel enough has been done. Cecil pours tea for Ehrlichman, glances at him, but Ehrlichman doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: HALDEMAN
dialogues.text: And the Southern Strategy is clearly working. We gained momentum in ‘68, but we think we can flip the South for good in ‘72. Nixon thinks it over, stares at Cecil who pours tea.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: There’s this whole black power movement going on, right? What if Nixon promotes black power to mean black businesses, and we find ways to support black entrepreneurs. We pass the buck on desegregation to the courts, but push black enterprise to win over the 20% that could vote our way. Haldeman and Erhlichman exchange glances, they love it.

dialogues.speaker: HALDEMAN
dialogues.text: That’s excellent, sir. Cecil picks up his tray and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: We just need to make sure that ‘Nixon’s black power’ doesn’t equate Nixon with the Black Panthers. Cecil pauses for a slight beat.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: God no! Did you read Hoover's memo?! It’s terrifying. I gave him the green light to go after them with all we got. Cecil’s eyes shut in pain as he walks out the door.  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten BLACK PANTHERS, all in black jackets and berets, load shotguns in a smoked filled room. The leader of this grou ELDRIDGE HUDGINS, 29, black, muscular, loads his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE HUDGINS
dialogues.text: Always beware of the nigger with a gun. A few people in the room laugh, but Louis is uncomfortabl He looks around at the guns, the smoke, just doesn’t like what he sees. He whispers to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I got to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis speaks to Carol in the hall outside the room.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We should get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: This is a mistake. We should go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I was always proud to be in jail...but I don’t think I’d be proud to be there for what we're about to do. Carol looks stunned. Eldridge Huggins sticks his head out

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE HUGGINS
dialogues.text: Is there a problem here?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Louis wants to leave. Eldridge Huggins stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE HUGGINS
dialogues.text: You scared, brother?  95.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m scared, and I’m not your brother.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE HUGGINS
dialogues.text: What about you, soul sister? You gonna go with this jive ass peckerwood? Carol looks at Louis, then at Eldridge Huggins.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, soul brother, I’m with you. She walks over to Huggins and puts her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not getting beat no mo’, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis walks down a quiet Oakland street, deeply disturbed POLICE CAR slowly drives by him, then continues on its wa Louis watches the car for a moment, then runs after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Panthers are staked out with their shotguns - one beh a tree, two behind a house, three more behind a fence. Ca grips her shotgun, but now she looks unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis runs toward the police car that’s half a mile down street. He waves his arms at the police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car slowly drives down the block looking for a address, inching closer toward its assassins. The Panthers give each other slight nods. Carol nods back but she’s starting to sweat, doesn’t want to do this now. Right when the car gets in their cross hairs, the Panther start BLASTING away. BANG! BANG! BANG! Carol watches for a second, then starts BLASTING as she screams in rage.  96. Louis appears at the head of the block and sees the firin squad. Police sirens can be heard off in the distance as Panthers immediately take off running. Carol sees Louis at the head of the block. They stare at other, Carol with shame in her eyes. Then she runs off. Louis watches her go as the sirens get louder and louder. Finally, he runs away. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Cecil drives down the street that still has many burnt do buildings from the ‘68 riot. A few new storefronts have opened that sell incense, candles and African clothes. Men and woman have AFROS and wear colorful DASHIKIS. A se of AFRICAN PRIDE has been infused into the neighborhood. Cecil eyes it all, just doesn’t know what to make of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into the house and sees Gloria on the couch watching news coverage of Watergate. NEWSCAST V.O. “The White House continues to deny any involvement in the break in at the Watergate hotel.”

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Can you please turn that off? I have to deal with Watergate everyday at work, I don’t want to deal with it at home.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well, I can’t live in ignorance just because your boss is a two bit criminal with a gang of Cuban thugs on his payroll.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: A gang of what?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: The plumbers.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: The what?  97.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Nixon’s henchmen. The same guys that broke into Daniel Ellsberg’s psychiatrist office were behind the Watergate break-in’s, it’s obvious this is a conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do about it? Quit?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Cuz if the staff quit every time a President did something we didn’t like, there’d be no staff! Gloria feels bad, kisses him on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, baby. The whole thing just makes me upset.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: And when did you start getting so worked up about politics?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: When he didn’t appoint a black cabinet member. Not one single black man in his entir-- Just then - they see a MILITARY CAR drive slowly down the street. They hurry to the window to see the car pull up t house. Out walks a MILITARY OFFICER and a PRIEST.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Cecil and Gloria hurry out of the house, they look terrif Many neighbors are coming out of their homes as the Offic and Priest knock on a front door. The door opens revealing Gina, she stares at them in mort fear. Before they can speak she screams:

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: No! Not my Elroy! No! Cecil has hurried over and holds her as she WAILS in pain  98.

dialogues.speaker: GINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please God! Not my Elroy! NOT MY

dialogues.speaker: ELROY
dialogues.text: The neighbors all surround Gina, many are crying. Cecil continues to hold Gina as she wails in his arms. CECIL V.O. I never felt more lost in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil ties a black tie around his shirt colla CECIL V.O. Everything was changin’ around me so fast. Vietnam took our Elroy and Gloria was startin’ to drift away. (Then) Everywhere I turned, someone new was leavin’ me behind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stands in front of the entire White House staff wit Pat and his two daughters.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I want you all to know that I leave with deep regret in my heart. You lifted me up during the tough moments and for that I will always be grateful. Several of the staff are crying, but not Cecil. He stares Nixon with a bitter detachment.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We think that when we suffer a defeat, that all is ended. He looks right at Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the greatness comes when you are really tested... Cecil looks surprised, never thought he’d ever be tested.  99.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--because only if you've been in the deepest valley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Houseman shuts the back of the moving van. NIXON V.O. ...Can you ever know how magnificent it is to be on the highest mountain. Right as the moving van drives off, an identical moving v pulls up in its place. We hear the voice of GERALD FORD:

dialogues.speaker: GERALD FORD
dialogues.text: I, Gerald Rudolph Ford, do solemnly swear-— The moving van immediately pulls off and a new moving van pulls up right where it was parked. We hear the distinct southern twang of our next President:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I, Jimmy Carter, do solemnly Swear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff hurries through the Central Hall, bringing in t Carter’s new furniture that has a distinct country flair. The new Chief Usher, SCOTT REXFORD, mid-40’s, clean cut, oversees the melee, he is much warmer than RD Warner.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT REXFORD
dialogues.text: 38 minutes to go. You all are doing great! Willie Nelson’s ‘On the Road Again’, plays over the seque

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new President, JIMMY CARTER, 52, cherub-like, exudes warmth and charm. He feels like a sweet uncle. He wears a apron as he pours green water from a pot into a bowl.  100.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The juice from the collared greens contains an abundance of the vegetable’s minerals and vitamins. (Big smile) We call it pot likker. The Chef grins, but a little worried that his culinary sk are going to be under utilized for the next four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘On the Road Again’ continues as Jimmy’s daughter, AMY, 9 round nerdy glasses, roller skates through the Cross Hall Cecil jumps out of the way holding a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge Southern style BBQ is taking place on the South La with a crawfish boil, piles of corn bread and BBQ. WILLIE NELSON is up on a stage singing ‘On The Road Again’. Jimmy dances with his wife, ROSALYN, pretty and charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Carter stands at a podium in front of the press cor

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: .--and that is why I am proud to appoint the country’s first black female Cabinet member, Patricia Harris, as head of Housing and Urban Development. PATRICIA HARRIS, 52, black, walks up to the podium. Cecil applauds, then stops, remembering he’s not supposed to cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria beams with pride at a big front page photo on the Washington Post of Patricia Harris. She looks up, thinking...this sparks something in her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria walks into the office of the Combahee River Collective. It’s filled with young black woman in their 2 and 30’s. Many of them with bushy Afros.  101. Posters cover the walls with pictures of black women marc in rallies with the slogan - “A SEPARATE ROAD TO FEMINISM female STAFF MEMBER look up at the older Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Gloria doesn’t respond, she looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria sits in a small office across from BARBARA SMITH, wears an army jacket. She has a tough, but cool vibe.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA SMITH
dialogues.text: Our goal is to gain female equality by calling attention to racism, sexism, homophobia and classicism to ensure that the most discriminated individual in American society, the black woman, will no longer be ignored. Gloria has a stunned look on her face, doesn’t know what say. Barbara Smith can tell she is overwhelmed. BARBARA SMITH (CONT’D) So tell me, Gloria, what exactly brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well, my son was a civil rights activist in the sixtie--

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA SMITH
dialogues.text: The black woman was completely left behind by the Civil Rights movement. It was always ‘One Man, One Vote’, the word ‘woman’ was never mentioned even though we were an integral part of the struggle. Slight beat. BARBARA SMITH (CONT’D) I’m sorry, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I just feel like I’ve spent the last 20 years watching the world go by on my television. (Then) I don’t want to watch no more.  102. Barbara Smith smiles at Gloria, likes her.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA SMITH
dialogues.text: I think you’d fit in nicely here.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You don’t think I’m too old?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA SMITH
dialogues.text: You're never too old to fight for social justice. (Then) So what is your son doing these days? Gloria goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: We haven't spoken in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in a suit and tie, Louis stands at a podium in fr of a medium sized audience of about 100 people. A banner above him announces ‘STATE ASSEMBLY DEBATE’. The room is sparsely decorated, a low budget operation, b Louis passionately addresses the modest crowd. In his mid 30's now, he’s lost a little hair and gained a few pounds

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: With the economy spiraling out of control, there is no greater time for Affirmative Action than now. I know these measures are not popular with white voters, as they seem to feel that racism is a thing of the past, but the truth is that black America is still significantly disadvantaged due to past and present discrimination. The MODERATOR turns to Louis main competitor, KEITH ALANS black conservative in a bow tie, he speaks from a podium.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH ALANS
dialogues.text: Mr. Gains and I may share the same skin color, but that is all we share. Affirmative Action is racism in reverse and it only creates more hostility by causing whites to resent blacks. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KEITH ALANS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If the black man wants to succeed he must do it with his own achievements.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You can’t kick a man in the dirt for 400 years and then accuse him of being dirty.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH ALANS
dialogues.text: Even our liberal President agrees that Affirmative Action should be phased out as he has already begun slashing these programs. Louis shoots him an icy look.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: To my great disappointment, President Carter is not a liberal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Carter sits across from the Black Congressional Cau They are stern with him, all look frustrated. Their leade REP. JOHN CONYERS, 49, tough, no nonsense. Cecil refills everyone's glasses with waters. He seems focused on the water, but it’s clear he’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: REP. JOHN CONYERS
dialogues.text: You received 94% of the black vote in the second closest election of the century, Mr. President. We elected you, and I’m sorry to say that we feel betrayed by these cuts to social programs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: My first priority has got to be getting inflation down or the economy is going to continue to spiral out of control.

dialogues.speaker: REP. JOHN CONYERS
dialogues.text: Which is exactly why we need more economic investment in the inner cities, not less. White businesses have fled in droves and it has created rampant black unemployment.  104.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It’s not just the black community that is suffering--

dialogues.speaker: REP. JOHN CONYERS
dialogues.text: --but we are disproportionately affected.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I've got to keep the budgets tight, everyone is just going to have to learn to get by with less. The black leaders exchange frustrated glances. John Conye rises to his feet. Cecil looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: REP. JOHN CONYERS
dialogues.text: We’re used to getting less, Mr. President, we were just hoping for more from you. He walks out of the room, Cecil looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small campaign headquarters is covered in deflated balloons that matches everyone’s deflated spirit. The onl person not upset is Louis who tries to cheer everyone up.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I know everyone is disappointed, and no one more so than me. But we have to remember that even though we lost tonight, we need to celebrate that another brother has won an election. Now I know he may not be our kind of brother... Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-but a black man is going to the state assembly and for that we should all be thrilled. Polite applause.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten years ago we couldn’t even vote in the South and now we’ve got brothers and sisters in Congress and state offices. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maynard Jackson is the mayor of Atlanta, Tom Bradley in Los Angeles, Carl Stokes, Shirley Chisolm, Barbara Jordan and the list goes on and on! We are doing it! We are starting to live the American dream! Everyone is applauding like crazy now. Even though Louis lost, he looks like a leader.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been through so many dark times, but in all those years gettin’ beat and thrown in prison, I never thought I’d see the day that I would have to give a concession speech. The room gives a warm and joyous applause to this.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to thank you all for your hard work, and I want to thank my beautiful wife, Sarah, for all those long hours on the trail. Everyone applauds Louis’ gorgeous wife, SARAH, 30, black. smiles at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This isn’t the end tonight, it’s only the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is on the phone as Gloria anxiously waits for news. Cecil’s eyes drop, so do Gloria’s.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (INTO THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Thank you, I appreciate it. He hangs up, turns to his wife. Then sadly shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He lost 51 to 49%. Gloria cringes at how close it was.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Should we call him?  106.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s been so long. Do you think he wants to hear from us tonight? Gloria shrugs, isn’t sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has emptied out a bit. Louis lounges on a couch, arms clutched around Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I still can’t believe I lost to that honky nigger. She busts up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone knows the fool only got into Harvard because of Affirmative Action! What’s the matter with these people?! An AIDE yells from the other end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Louis, you got a phone call. Louis walks over to the phone, picks it up. He hears: CAROL V.O. I’m so sorry you lost. Louis sits up, obviously hasn’t heard from her in years.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is in a prison uniform in a federal penitentiary. H arms are covered in prison tatoos, she’s been here for ye

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I love you, Louis. I’m sorry I never could say that before, but I really do love you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What happened? Where did you go?  107.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t ever forget that, okay, baby, please don’t ever forget it. She hangs up. Louis slowly hangs up the phone, then looks over at his w He smiles at his beautiful Sarah...happy with his life. EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - WASHINGTON DC - DAY Driving to work, Cecil sees several boarded up buildings ‘FOR RENT’ and ‘FORECLOSED’ signs. All of the African-Pri stores have shut down and no new businesses are moving in CECIL V.O. Every where I looked, it seemed like another black man was losin’ somethin’ new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil eyes the headline on Booker’s newspaper: ‘SUPREME C RULES FOR BAKKE, ENDS RACIAL QUOTAS.” CECIL V.O. And for the first time, I was startin’ to get mad. INT. WHITE HOUSE - CHIEF USHER’S OFFICE - DAY Cecil sits across from the Chief Usher, Scott Rexford.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I’ve been here for twenty years now, and for all that time, the black help has been getting a smaller salary than the white help. I just don’t think it’s right. Scott Rexford is much warmer than the previous Chief Ushe

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT REXFORD
dialogues.text: I don’t think it is either, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: And there are black housemen who should be engineers by now, they should've been promoted years ago.  108.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT REXFORD
dialogues.text: I fully agree, and I plan on making several promotions immediately. The raises are going to be tougher because of the recession. Cecil smiles his warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I know that we’re in a recession, but I can’t wait out these excuses anymore. I have to be paid the same as the white help or I’1l have to move on. Silence. Scott Rexford is impressed at his forcefulness.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT REXFORD
dialogues.text: I know that no one wants that, including the President. I’1l get into it immediately.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s important that it’s not just me, all of the black help needs to get equal pay to the white staff. Scott Rexford smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT REXFORD
dialogues.text: We'll find a way to make this work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks up the stair landing with a small look of pri on his face, he sees Jimmy Carter sitting on the floor of Treaty Room tieing a fly fishing fly. Cecil stares at the President, he looks beaten up by the depressed. Jimmy sees Cecil through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You ever do much fishing, Cecil?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: My daddy used to take me fly fishing as a boy. (Then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet when I’m on my death bed, I‘1l think of my daddy, and I probably won’t even remember I was President. Cecil grins, but the conversation is a touch painful.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you close with your father? Cecil shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I never knew him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Cecil, that’s a real shame.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I sometimes wonder what he looked like.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: If he could see you now, I bet he’d be real proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I bet your father would be very proud of you, Mr. President. Slight beat.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I think he might be disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I don’t think so, Mr. President. His son made it to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We both made it, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Yes we did, Mr. President. Slight beat, Jimmy’s face falls knowing his doomed fate.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Except you’ll get to stay.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moving van is pulling out as a new moving van pulls in. hear the raspy older voice of our next president:

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I, Ronald Wilson Reagan, do solemnly swear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RONALD ‘RONNIE’ REAGAN, 69, exudes a sweet, likable quali He feels like a favorite Grandfather. He is in the kitche with the butlers and the kitchen staff telling them a jok

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: So the psychiatrist took the pessimistic brother to a room piled to the ceiling with brand-new toys. But instead of yelping with delight, the little boy burst into tears. "What's the matter? Don't you want to play with any of the toys,” asked the psychiatrist. "Yes," the little boy bawled, "but if I did I'd only break them." The staff is smiling, a few have already started laughing

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next the psychiatrist treated the optimistic brother. Trying to dampen his out look, he took him to a room piled to the ceiling with horse manure. The optimist yelped with delight, clambered to the top of the pile and began gleefully digging out scoop after scoop with his bare hands. A few people grimace, but Cecil is laughing. Ronnie start chuckle as he nears the punch line.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "What do you think you're doing?", the psychiatrist asked. (Then) "With all this manure," the optimistic boy replied, "there must be a pony in here somewhere!"  111. The whole room bust out in laughter, everyone is beaming, they love Ronald Reagan. Just then, his wife, NANCY, 59, walks into the room in a stylish red suit. As soon as she walks in, Ronnie tenses up a touch, become different person around Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good talking to everyone. He pecks Nancy on the cheek as he hurries out of the room Booker whispers to Cecil:

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Just like at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie sits with PAT BUCHANAN, 47, jowly, the Communicati Director. They are across from three Republican Senators, RICHARD LUGAR, 53, BOB DOLE, 62 and NANCY KASSEBAUM, 53. Cecil pours tea for Senator Dole who smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I want to make myself clear on this issue. If Congress passes sanctions against South Africa, I will be forced to veto those sanctions. Cecil stops pouring for a split second, then starts up ag

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR LUGAR
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we feel that you are missing a major point here.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Which is what, Senator Lugar? Cecil pours tea for Senator Kassebaum who nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR LUGAR
dialogues.text: The brutal repression of South Africa’s black citizens is no longer just a foreign policy issue. It’s a domestic civil rights issue. Pat Buchanan snaps at him.

dialogues.speaker: PAT BUCHANAN
dialogues.text: If we impose sanctions on South African it will make us appear weak to Russia!  112. Cecil stands at the back, staring forward, it’s clear he’ listening. Senator Kassebaum turns to Ronnie with urgency

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR KASSEBAUM
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the three of us are Senators from your own party, you can’t get a friendlier room than this. That is why we feel so comfortable telling you that South Africa is a human rights disaster. Blacks are beaten, tortured and gunned down in the streets. The America people are horrified by Apartheid. Ronnie looks frustrated with the Senators.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Senator Kassebaum, but I will not show weakness to Russia by backing down on this issue.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR LUGAR
dialogues.text: But Mr. President, your own personal world leadership is at stake. The United States of America needs to be on the right side of history on the race issue. Ronnie looks at them all with his iron will, when he is convinced he’s right, nothing can change his mind.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Let me be clear so that there’s no confusion, if Congress passes this bill, I will veto it. Period. Pat Buchanan smiles at the three Republican Senators who stare at Ronnie, they can’t believe it. Cecil also stares at Ronnie, he can’t believe it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil pours out the left over tea from his teapot. He loo disturbed on a deep level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie sits alone behind his desk, he is writing a check for $2000. Cecil walks in.  113.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I have a secret mission for you, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I like to send people money when they write me about their financial problems, but my staff has been trying to get me to stop. You think you could help me keep this going? Ronnie places the check in an envelope and hands it to Ce

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Absolutely, Mr. President. Ronnie looks up at him, something on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Cecil, did you ever go to those civil rights rallies in the sixties?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: No, sir, I was too old for that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. Ronnie looks troubled, trying to work through his feeling

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This whole civil rights issue...I sometimes fear I’m on the wrong side of it...that I’m just wrong. He turns to Cecil, a touch lost.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think? Cecil stares at him, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil stares into the video camera, still ama  114.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Never in my life had a President of the United States asked me what I thought about anything.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: So what did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I told him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil smiles at the President with understanding.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I sometimes think the same thing about myself, Mr. President. Ronnie nods. Then points at the envelope with the check -

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I appreciate your help with our little project. And don’t tell Nancy about it.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I won’t, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cecil walks into the hallway he hears from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Cecil. Cecil tenses up, quickly puts the envelope in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Reagan?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're very well liked around here. Everyone says you’re the man that got them raises and promotions. I had no idea you were such a rebel. How'd you get to be like that? Cecil smiles, trying to play it off like a joke.  115.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
