dialogues.text: I’m not a rebel, Mrs. Reagan, it just seemed like it was time. She smiles at him, clearly likes Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you because I’d like to personally invite you to the State Dinner next week.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: But I’m going to be there, Mrs. Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, Cecil, not as a butler, I’m inviting you as a guest. Cecil is stunned, doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: But...the President prefers for me to serve him personally.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about, Ronnie. I‘11l take care of that. So we’ll see you and your wife next week, yes?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (Stunned) Yes, Ma’m.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a three piece tux, Cecil walks out of his house w Gloria who is in a ball gown. They are greeted with a wil round of applause from the neighbors who are all outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is being escorted by a Military aide toward the Ea Room. She looks around in total amazement, Cinderella at ball. Cecil wanders behind her like all the other male da

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: Can I get you champagne, Mr. Gains? Cecil slaps him on the shoulder.  116.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Oh, come on now! Booker starts to laugh. Then from behind them they hear:

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY AIDE
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman, the President and First Lady of the United States. The Military Band begins ‘Hail to the Chief’ as Ronnie an Nancy walk down the hall to great fanfare. Gloria stares at Nancy who greets all of her guests with charisma. Gloria is in awe of Nancy as she whispers to Ce

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: She’s so strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are seated at separate tables as all of the butlers smile at Cecil, very proud. A BUTLER serves him tomato so

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: This one is made special, Mr. Gains.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Oh, come on now! Cecil glances over at Gloria who is seated near Nancy, sh beams at the First Lady who is controlling the table. Cecil looks around at all of the butlers serving the room carefully setting down dishes, refilling water and wine glasses. They are an impressive, well oiled machine. But Cecil’s smile slowly starts to drop. He doesn’t know but he doesn’t like what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil looks confused at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It was real different sittin’ at the table instead of servin’ it. Real different.  117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil walks into the kitchen where Chef Luke is preparing glorious chocolate mouse. All of the staff looks confused

dialogues.speaker: CHEF LUKE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I wanted to see if you needed any help.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF LUKE
dialogues.text: Get back up there!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Alright, alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the guests are having after dinner drinks. Cecil look even more unhappy, but Gloria is shinning, outgoing. Book walks over, whispers to Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: How’s it going, blood?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Real nice. (Then) Be even nicer if I was here for real instead of for show. Booker smiles at Cecil with empathy, he finally gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk into the house, Gloria is on cloud nine, still high from the night. Cecil looks conflicted, almost confu

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I think that was one of the greatest nights of my life. Cecil smiles, but it’s clear he had a different experienc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is asleep, but Cecil lies wide awake.  118. CECIL V.O. I couldn't understand why such a lovely night would cause me so much trouble. He looks over at Gloria who is sound asleep with a big sm

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It had a whole different effect on Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge rally is taking place with hundreds of black women facing a stage where a nervous Gloria stands at a microph

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I’m just a quiet house wife from Washington DC, I never once saw myself as having the courage to stand up in front of people and speak out. (Then) But for far too long the black woman has lived in the shadows. I say it is time we step out from the dark and let our voices be heard! The crowd roars with approval, no one louder than Cecil. as Gloria continues her speech, Cecil looks a touch lost. CECIL V.O. The more Gloria came into her own, the more confused I felt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil passes out cookies to people in the White House tou he looks unhappy. CECIL V.O. For the first time in 34 years I started to feel restless at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is washing dishes, looks almost angry. CECIL V.O. I felt like I didn’t know who I was anymore.  119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil is wearing a tie and pants, he cleans o his suit jacket with a lint brush.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Then I remembered that the last time I felt this way was after I read those books when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is in a library looking at the stacks of books. CECIL V.O. So I figured they might explain to me why I was upset again all these years later. He pulls a copy of ‘EYES ON THE PRIZE’ off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits at a table reading the book. There is a picture f 1960 of the black students at the sit-ins being taunted. CECIL V.O. I remembered when this happened, but I didn’t know how bad it got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil reads ‘RACE, REFORM AND REBELLION’ about the Freedo Riders, there is a picture of the burning bus. CECIL V.O. Readin’ about these kids made me embarrassed about how wrong I had been about them at first. They were never criminals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil sits on the couch reading ‘PILLAR OF FIRE’, there a pictures of the various student protestors. CECIL V.O. ...they were heroes. All of them. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: James Bevel, John Lewis, Ella Baker, Stokey Carmichael, Bernard Lafayette, Carol Nash. He turns the page and there is a full page picture of Lou holding a sign that says ‘I AM A MAN.’ Cecil is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then there he was, my boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil smiles into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: ...right along the rest of them. For the first time we see the CAMERA MAN - It’s Louis, now 66, he’s bald with grey temples. Tears ro down his cheek as he listens to his father. Cecil smiles his son, so proud.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had barely spoken for almost ten years, and when I saw your picture I realized that it had been the worst ten years of my life. I never knew I could miss someone as much I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I missed you too, Dad, I missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: When you were born I promised you that nuthin’ was gonna ever tear us apart... EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - WASHINGTON DC - DAY Cecil walks down the street, there is still rubble from t ‘68 riots, most of the buildings are run down and boarded a DRUG DEALER on the corner, a PROSTITUTE on another. CECIL V.O. ..-and now it was time to keep my promise.  121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of protestors are outside the South African Emba with signs ‘Freedom in South Africa’ and ‘End Apartheid’. Louis is at the front of the crowd standing next to Amy Carter, who is now 18. Louis talks to a REPORTER.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Twenty-five years ago we marched in this country for our rights, today we march to free the people of South Africa! The crowd cheers around him.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Were you surprised by President Reagan's veto?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Ronald Reagan has attacked or dismantled every civil rights program that has ever been put in to place. Aiding the oppression of black South Africans is consistent with his policies on race issu--. Louis stops talking as he sees Cecil watching him from ac the street. Louis is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please excuse me for a minute. The Reporter moves on to Amy Carter.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Amy, does your father, former President Carter approve of what you are doing here? Louis walks up to Cecil. The two of them stare at each ot for a long beat. It’s been so many years.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Hi, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I came here to protest with you.  122.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: But we’re gonna get arrested, you'll lose your job.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I resigned today. Louis is shocked, can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Why? Cecil smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I want to join the Beloved Community. Louis beams as he wraps his arms around his dad in a huge hug. This time, he’s the one that doesn’t want to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Louis sit side by side in a holding cell cramme with 20 other protestors. Cecil looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Dad, we’ll be out ina few hours.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: How many times have you been arrested?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Sixty-three. Cecil is stunned, had no idea. They sit for a moment. The Cecil starts to sing:

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: ‘We shall overcome. We shall overcome. Louis joins in with him -

dialogues.speaker: CECIL AND LOUIS
dialogues.text: ‘We shall overcome someday.’ They continue singing into the next scene...  123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Gloria are twenty years older with full heads o grey hair. Cecil helps Gloria gingerly walk down their bl ‘BARACK OBAMA FOR PRESIDENT’ signs are on every lawn. CECIL AND LOUIS V.O. ‘We are not afraid. We are not afraid... EXT. CECIL’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY They continue their walk through the neighborhood, it has been revitalized, lots of new buildings and stores, no mo rubble. ‘BARACK OBAMA FOR PRESIDENT’ signs in every windo CECIL AND LOUIS V.O. ‘,..we are not afraid someday.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up a tree lined street to an elementary school a sign - ‘Polling Station #54. Vote here on November 4!’ stare at it for a long moment, then Gloria tears up.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: My grandparents were born slaves, and in a week I’m gonna come here and vote for a black man to be President of the United States. She turns to Cecil with tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never in my wildest dreams did I ever imagine this could happen in my lifetime, and now I’m not only gonna see it, but I’m gonna be a part of it. Cecil takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Ain’t it something, honey bear.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It sure is, baby doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil helps Gloria gingerly sit down on to their bed.  124.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Reagan did what?!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: He’d have me send checks to people that sent him letters about how poor they were.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: So the man cuts welfare benefits for millions, but sent poor people money out of his own pocket?! Cecil shrugs. Gloria thinks for a moment, then confesses:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I kept sending Louis money after you told me to stop.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Years. Cecil stares at her, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I did too.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: He never knew it was from me. They both start to laugh as Cecil walks into the bathroom

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I stopped after the fight, but I didn’t want to. How much would you send him? She doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much did you send him? He walks back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey bea--?  125. He stops as he sees that Gloria is passed out in an unusu position. Cecil immediately knows that something is wrong

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil is at a podium in front of a packed church next to casket. The audience is filled with a huge crowd, watchin Cecil eulogizes with a joy at his Gloria’s beautiful life

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: As a poor negro girl growing up in the deep south, never in her wildest dreams did my beautiful wife think she would lead marches and rallies in front of hundreds of black women. The audience applauds.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a poor negro girl in the deep south, never in her wildest dreams did my beautiful wife dream that she would she see her son become a United States Congressman. Louis smiles as the audience applauds the Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as a poor negro girl in the South, never in her wildest dreams would my beautiful wife think she’d see her husband arrested for protesting the Iraq War. Both of them! Wild applause.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The story of my Gloria, is the story of this country. She lived most of her life quiet in the shadows, afraid to lift her head. But when the truth became clear, she found the courage to speak her mind. Not just as a black woman, but as a proud American. She lived a wonderful life, and I am so proud to know her. My family’s only regret...  126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis is in the basement of his father’s house. He looks all pictures on the walls of Cecil with all of the presidents, but instead of the actors that played the Presidents, it’s Cecil with the actual Presidents. CECIL V.O. ..-is that she never got to vote for a black man, an African- American, for President of the United States. Louis looks at a black and white photo of Cecil with Ike. picture of Cecil serving LBJ. A bronze bust of Robert Ken sits next to JFK’s tie that Jackie gave him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But in my heart I’1l know that she will see his victory... A picture of Cecil, Booker and Carter smiling with Nixon next to a picture of Cecil and Nancy Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-.-she’ll be up in Heaven smiling down with all of our ancestors... He looks at the book case that is filled with dozens of b on African-American history. He pulls a book off the shel and starts to thumb through the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+.-So proud of how far America has come. He stops at - a picture of the smiling Emmet Till. All th years later, the image is still very painful for him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL V.0O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Louis! Get up here! Louis hurries up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is packed with people - Cecil, Louis, Sar Booker, Carter, Howard, Gina and her new husband. Lots of kids and grandchildren. All eyes are glued on the TV:  127.

dialogues.speaker: CNN ANCHOR
dialogues.text: We can officially announce that Barack Obama will be the 44th President of the United State. The room screams in joy, hugs and tears.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: The real footage of President Barack Obama, his wife Michelle, and their daughters, Sasha and Malia, standing stage in Grant Park waving to the crowd of thousands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the Gains house watches the TV in awe as President Barack Obama and his family wave to the crowd. There are no tears, no cheers, no noise, just silence, stunned silence as they stare at the new First Family. Lo and Cecil both turn to each other, they can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: BARACK OBAMA
dialogues.text: “If there is anyone out there who still doubts that America is a place where all things are possible; who still wonders if the dream of our founders is alive in our time; who still questions the power of our democracy, tonight is your answer.” Cecil puts his arm around Louis, holds his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 year old Cecil wears the suit that he has been prepari the whole film as he ties a tie on Louis.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: So let me ask you a question, Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?  128.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Why did you have to make your dad worry about you so much all those years? Louis thinks about it, then:

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: So one day he could meet the man we're about to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Louis sit in the Entrance Hall of the White Hou Cecil looks around - the paintings, the sculptures, the clocks - it truly is American splendor. Through a door, he sees the HEAD BUTLER, black, teaching new young butler. All of the china, flatware and stem war are lined up exactly how they were when Freddie taught Ce Cecil can’t help but notice that both butlers are black. maid walks by, she is Mexican. Two housemen carry an anti wooden bench down the hall. They are both black. Cecil’s eyes drop ever so slightly. Then, the new Chief Usher, ADMIRAL STEPHEN ROCHON, black, walks up to them.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ROCHON
dialogues.text: Mr. Gains, Congressman Gains, I’m Admiral Rochon, the Chief Usher. Cecil looks surprised that he’s African-American.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It’s nice to meet you, Admiral. Did you sign on with President Obama?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ROCHON
dialogues.text: No, I started with President Bush. The last one.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (Smiles) Well that’s just fine.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ROCHON
dialogues.text: I just wanted to tell you what an honor it is to meet you both.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The honor is ours, Admiral.  129. Admiral Rochon gestures toward the State Dining Room.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ROCHON
dialogues.text: President Obama is ready for you. They look at each other as they get up and walk down the toward the State Dining Room passing all the Presidential portraits - LBJ, NIXON, IKE, CARTER, REAGAN AND JFK. The Secret Service opens the door as they see the back of PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA. He is looking up at the great painting of Abraham Lincoln that hangs above the mantel. A smile forms on Cecil’s face as the butler and his son w toward the first black President of the United States. FADE TO BLACK.
